Amanda Silberling, Author at TechCrunch
2023
https://techcrunch.com/author/amanda-silberling

Amanda Silberling Elon Musk’s Twitter a year later: Everything you need to know Amanda Silberling , Alyssa Stringer Kids on Roblox are hosting protests for Palestine Amanda Silberling All I want from the internet is Homer Simpson singing ‘Smells Like Teen Spirit’ Amanda Silberling Discord is growing its developer monetization efforts Amanda Silberling After 50,000 hours, this AI can play Pokémon Red Amanda Silberling When was the last time Marc Andreessen talked to a poor person? Amanda Silberling , Dominic-Madori Davis , Kyle Wiggers Trust & Safety Tycoon lets you simulate the most agonizing job in tech Amanda Silberling FTC sues bankrupt crypto company Voyager’s CEO over false FDIC insurance claims Amanda Silberling Creators raising venture capital: Unsettling or genius? Amanda Silberling VidCon is still kickin’ Amanda Silberling How an AI deepfake ad of MrBeast ended up on TikTok Amanda Silberling X (Twitter) has paid almost $20M to creators, CEO says Amanda Silberling X will be profitable in 2024, CEO claims in tense interview Amanda Silberling Mark Zuckerberg went 33 minutes without saying ‘metaverse’ at his keynote Amanda Silberling The writers’ strike is over; here’s how AI negotiations shook out Amanda Silberling Hollywood strikes could soon extend to the video game industry Amanda Silberling Reddit will start paying you real money for good posts Amanda Silberling Meta’s Horizon Worlds is rolling out on web and mobile Amanda Silberling Load More "speakable-summary\"> "font-weight: 400;\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/wework\/\">WeWork<\/a> is on the verge of filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in New Jersey, according to sources cited by The <\/span> "https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/wework-plans-to-file-for-bankruptcy-as-early-as-next-week-1fdcb6a5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">Wall Street Journal<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">.<\/span><\/p>\n If WeWork does indeed file, it shouldn’t come as a shock to close followers of the f "font-weight: 400;\">lexible workspace provider. WeWork warned in August in its "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/08\/wework-goes-from-a-47b-valuation-to-subtantial-doubts-about-its-ability-to-continue-as-a-going-concern\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">second-quarter earnings<\/a> that<\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">\u00a0\u201csubstantial doubt exists about the company\u2019s ability to continue as a going concern.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">The company has faced a number of challenges for years as demand for its co-working spaces has steadily declined over time. Those troubles compounded during the COVID pandemic when\u00a0<\/span> "font-weight: 400;\">companies abandoned office space and employees began working remotely. Even as some companies have returned to the office, the appetite for WeWork space didn’t rebound to those pre-pandemic days.<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">Earlier this month, WeWork missed interest payments to its bondholders, and was granted 30 days to come up with those payments, according to <\/span> "https:\/\/d18rn0p25nwr6d.cloudfront.net\/CIK-0001813756\/75fb45d7-d40d-4f34-95e0-51188ec72bb8.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">a securities filing<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">. On October 30, WeWork said it had begun discussions with \u201ccertain stakeholders in its capital structure\u201d such as SoftBank and Goldman Sachs about improving its balance sheet as it took steps \u201cto rationalize its real estate footprint.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">In August, the 13-year-old company announced a net loss of $397 million for the second quarter on revenue of $877 million. While revenue was up 4% year-over-year, WeWork interim CEO David Tolley noted in a statement at the time: \u201cExcess supply in commercial real estate, increasing competition in flexible space and macroeconomic volatility drove higher member churn and softer demand than we anticipated, resulting in a slight decline in memberships.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n "font-weight: 400;\">The company\u2019s stock was <\/span> "https:\/\/finance.yahoo.com\/quote\/WE\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "font-weight: 400;\">down over 47% after-hours today<\/span><\/a> "font-weight: 400;\">, trading at just $1.21 and hitting a new 52-week low. This gave the company a market cap of just $121 million, a stark contrast to the $47 billion valuation it reached after raising $1 billion in its SoftBank-led Series H round in January 2019.<\/span><\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"0pILKwA92b\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/wework-fires-back-at-competitor-codi-with-cease-and-desist\/\">WeWork fires back at competitor Codi with cease and desist following ‘WeWont’ campaign<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“WeWork fires back at competitor Codi with cease and desist following ‘WeWont’ campaign” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/wework-fires-back-at-competitor-codi-with-cease-and-desist\/embed\/#?secret=vSprtrVfCm#?secret=0pILKwA92b\" data-secret=\"0pILKwA92b\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" WeWork is on the verge of filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in New Jersey, according to sources cited by The Wall Street Journal. If WeWork does indeed file, it shouldn’t come as a shock to close followers of the flexible workspace provider. WeWork warned in August in its second-quarter earnings that\u00a0\u201csubstantial doubt exists about the WeWork, which lets freelancers and other non-traditional workers to become members in a shared or flexible office space, has expanded globally over the last year but continues to suffer large losses. While in 2018 WeWork saw a more than doubling of its sales to $1.82 billion from a year earlier, the company\u2019s losses over that same period also more than doubled to $1.93 billion. | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"description":"Read the latest news about WeWork on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US","isAccessibleForFree":"True","hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","isAccessibleForFree":"True"}},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/60650386"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=60650386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=60650386"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622647,"date":"2023-10-31T14:02:07","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:02:07","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622647"},"modified":"2023-10-31T15:14:19","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T22:14:19","slug":"google-and-match-group-reach-settlement-in-app-store-antitrust-case","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/google-and-match-group-reach-settlement-in-app-store-antitrust-case\/","title":{"rendered":"Google and Match Group reach settlement in app store antitrust case"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Google and Match announced today they’ve reached a settlement in the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/19\/epic-and-matchs-antitrust-case-against-google-heads-to-jury-trial-on-november-6\/\">antitrust battle Match waged against the tech giant,<\/a> even as the court case continues with Fortnite maker Epic Games. As part of the settlement agreement, Match Group — which owns dating apps Tinder, Hinge, OKCupid, Match.com and others — will be able to implement “ "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/02\/google-will-allow-alternative-payment-systems-for-play-store-in-more-countries\/\">user choice billing<\/a>” by March 31, 2024. This feature allows users to pay with other systems besides Google’s own.<\/p>\n Spotify and Bumble were among the initial testers for the new system, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/10\/google-play-to-pilot-third-party-billing-in-new-markets-including-u-s-bumble-joins-spotify-as-early-tester\/\">first introduced in November 2022<\/a>. Since then, Spotify’s third-party billing option "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/31\/spotifys-third-party-billing-option-has-now-reached-over-140-global-markets\/\"> rolled out to worldwide markets<\/a> as Google expanded user choice billing to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/10\/google-play-to-pilot-third-party-billing-in-new-markets-including-u-s-bumble-joins-spotify-as-early-tester\/\">more countries outside the U.S.<\/a><\/p>\n The program, so far, has not allowed third-party app markers that charge users for purchases and subscriptions to do away entirely with the commission Google requires. Instead, it offers a small percentage off the standard 15% to 30% commission. Currently, that discount is 4%, "https:\/\/support.google.com\/googleplay\/android-developer\/answer\/12570971\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">per Google’s help documentation.<\/a> The program is also still a pilot open to all developers globally who are selling apps to users in the supported 35 markets where it’s now available. Google has not said when the program will become globally available.<\/p>\n As part of the agreement, Match Group will not be allowed to only<\/em> offer its own billing system — it will offer its system alongside the existing Google Play billing system. Users will be able to choose which way they want to pay.<\/p>\n In addition, the settlement agreement includes a provision that Google will continue to work with Match Group in other areas where the two companies partner, including in Google Cloud and in the use of Google’s AI technologies, a Google spokesperson said. This suggests that the rift between the two tech companies incurred by the lawsuit could have led to more complicated relationships across other areas of both Google and Match’s business.<\/p>\n Like Apple, Google has long stressed that its commission structure is not only based on its ability to process payments for its customers. Instead, it suggests that the fees help to support the entire Google Play and Android app ecosystem, including hosting, app discovery, developer tools and other resources necessary to create an app business.<\/p>\n But as larger companies like Match and Epic have argued, they don’t need the same resources as other developers. In fact, "https:\/\/www.fortnite.com\/mobile\/android\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">as Epic demonstrated<\/a>, they could self-distribute apps and manage their own payments. They believed they should then at least have the option to have a more direct relationship with their paying customers, and Google preventing this was an anti-competitive concern.<\/p>\n “We are pleased to reach a settlement agreement with Match Group,” a Google spokesperson said, in a prepared statement. “This ensures we can continue to provide our shared users the secure, seamless, and high-quality experience people expect from apps on Google Play while maintaining Google\u2019s ability to invest in the Android ecosystem and deliver value across an app\u2019s full lifecycle,” they added.<\/p>\n “Today, the Match plaintiffs and Google informed the court that they have reached a binding term sheet for a settlement of their respective claims against each other in the Match Group, LLC et al vs. Google LLC et al lawsuit. Under the terms, the $40 million placed in escrow will be returned to Match Group and no other amounts will be owed by the Match plaintiffs to Google relating to the claims in the lawsuit for the period ending December 31, 2023,” a Match Group statement added, shared alongside the release of its Q3 earnings results.<\/p>\n Recently, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/11\/google-pushes-match-for-more-money-in-antitrust-battle-court-filing-states\/\"> Google had pushed Match Group for more money in escrow<\/a>, saying that the $40 million would not be enough to cover the missed payments. (Match had been allowed to escrow funds to cover commissions while the lawsuit was underway.)<\/p>\n Match noted that the parties agreed that by March 31, 2024, its apps will implement Google\u2019s User Choice Billing, reducing its commission payments from 15% and 30% to 11% and 26%, respectively.<\/p>\n “The parties will enter a new partnership agreement that will provide value exchange across their broad relationship, which we expect will essentially offset the additional costs that Match Group brands expect to incur over the three years starting in 2024 associated with the implementation and continued use of User Choice Billing in compliance with Google\u2019s payment policy during that period,” Match Group also said.<\/p>\n In addition to the settlement news, Match Group reported a 9% year-over-year increase in revenue in Q3 to $882 million, with Tinder’s portion up 11% to $509 million.<\/p>\n It’s unclear whether this settlement will prompt Epic Games to also reach an agreement with the tech giant. If it does not, it’s set to go to trial next week to present its arguments.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"qGcXVnzmF8\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/19\/epic-and-matchs-antitrust-case-against-google-heads-to-jury-trial-on-november-6\/\">Epic and Match’s antitrust case against Google heads to jury trial on November 6<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Epic and Match’s antitrust case against Google heads to jury trial on November 6” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/19\/epic-and-matchs-antitrust-case-against-google-heads-to-jury-trial-on-november-6\/embed\/#?secret=0nyn1KtKRl#?secret=qGcXVnzmF8\" data-secret=\"qGcXVnzmF8\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"RLl8RYNyCh\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/google-asks-court-to-dismiss-multiple-claims-in-epic-games-antitrust-trial\/\">Google asks court to dismiss multiple claims in Epic Games antitrust trial<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; As part of the settlement agreement, Match Group — which owns dating apps Tinder, Hinge, OKCupid, Match.com and others — will be able to implement name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/79611524"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=79611524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=79611524"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2622575,"date":"2023-10-31T12:17:33","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T19:17:33","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622575"},"modified":"2023-10-31T14:50:30","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:50:30","slug":"tesla-wins-fatal-autopilot-crash-jury-trial","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/tesla-wins-fatal-autopilot-crash-jury-trial\/","title":{"rendered":"Tesla wins fatal Autopilot crash jury trial"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">A jury on Tuesday handed Tesla another win after siding with the automaker over allegations that its Autopilot advanced driver assistance system led to a death.<\/p>\n The case, which was being tried in the Superior Court of California, County of Riverside, was filed by two passengers who survived a 2019 crash and alleged that Tesla knew its product was defective. The two survivors sought $400 million in damages for the loss of the driver’s life, physical injury and mental anguish.<\/p>\n Tesla argued that the crash, which resulted in the death of the driver Micah Lee, was the result of human error \u2014 the same stance it’s taken in other Autopilot lawsuits.<\/p>\n While Tesla has won other lawsuits, including a California jury trial earlier this year that determined the automaker’s Autopilot system was not to blame for a 2019 crash. In that case, the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/21\/tesla-wins-autopilot-crash-case-in-california\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">jury awarded no damages<\/a> to Los Angeles resident Justine Hsu, who sued Tesla in 2020 alleging negligence, fraud and breach of contract. The Molander v. Tesla case that wrapped up Tuesday was the first jury trial involving a fatality.<\/p>\n Tesla still faces a number of other lawsuits in California, including a wrongful death suit that was filed by the family of Walter Huang, an Apple engineer who died after his Tesla Model X with Autopilot engaged crashed into a highway median. The State of California Department of Transportation is also named in the lawsuit. That wrongful death lawsuit, filed in California Superior Court, County of Santa Clara, alleges that errors by Tesla\u2019s Autopilot driver assistance system caused the crash that killed Huang on March 23, 2018. Huang, who was 38, died when his 2017 Tesla Model X hit a highway barrier on Highway 101 in Mountain View, California. A jury trial is expected to begin next year in that case.<\/p>\n Tesla is also facing scrutiny from "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/29\/nhtsa-raises-more-concerns-about-teslas-autopilot-safety\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">federal and state regulators,<\/a> all of which are related to Autopilot and its upgraded version known as Full Self-Driving.<\/p>\n Tesla vehicles come standard with a driver-assistance system branded as Autopilot. For a $6,000 upgrade, owners can purchase Enhanced Autopilot, which includes several other features, including an active guidance system that navigates a car from a highway on-ramp to off-ramp, including interchanges and making lane changes.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n For an\u00a0additional $12,000, owners can buy \u201cfull self-driving,\u201d or FSD \u2014 a feature that CEO\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/elon-musk\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/elon-musk\/\">Elon Musk<\/a>\u00a0has promised for years will one day deliver full autonomous driving capabilities.<\/p>\n Tesla vehicles\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/07\/tesla-refutes-elon-musks-timeline-on-full-self-driving\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/07\/tesla-refutes-elon-musks-timeline-on-full-self-driving\/\">are not self-driving<\/a>. Instead, FSD includes a number of automated driving features that still require the driver to be ready to take control at all times. It includes everything in Enhanced Autopilot and is supposed to handle steering on city streets and recognize and react to traffic lights and stop signs.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" A jury on Tuesday handed Tesla another win after siding with the automaker over allegations that its Autopilot advanced driver assistance system led to a death. The case, which was being tried in the Superior Court of California, County of Riverside, was filed by two passengers who survived a 2019 crash and alleged that Tesla ","title":{"rendered":"So long, Twitter Circles"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">If tic-tac-toe has taught us anything, it’s that Xs and circles cannot peacefully coexist.<\/p>\n X, the app formerly known as Twitter, has shut down the Circles feature, which allowed users to post to a small, exclusive audience. Like an Instagram Close Friends story, Circles — n\u00e9e Twitter Circles — offered a more intimate social media experience. In other words, you could overshare about your life to an audience of friends only, rather than the whole internet. And isn’t one of the greatest joys of the internet to emotionally shitpost without worrying about the consequences?<\/p>\n But, as the whims of the Circle reminded us, nothing we say on the internet is ever actually free from consequence. The feature worked almost all of the time. Almost. And anything less than 100% efficacy is not ideal for a feature that people used to share private thoughts with trusted friends.<\/p>\n As early as February, some users reported that their Circle tweets were "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/03\/twitter-circle-glitches-have-users-worried-about-privacy\/\">reaching a wider audience<\/a> than they were supposed to. These glitches showed up "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/10\/twitter-circle-bug-not-private\/\">again in April<\/a>, and X (then known as Twitter) "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/05\/twitter-confirms-circle-tweets-temporarily-were-not-private\/\">apologized<\/a> for the error in May, marking a rare moment of transparency for the company.<\/p>\n Even when Circle tweets were truly private, they often appeared not to be — the green banner denoting it as a Circle post only appeared some of the time (I had received some paranoid texts from friends who wondered if I knew I had posted about [redacted] on main, but nope, this was just the glitchy old bird app playing tricks on us).<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n "twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n "en\" dir=\"ltr\">I can't believe this website is going to take away my most treasured joke: my Twitter circle that only contains Tony Hawk.
"https:\/\/t.co\/P9pRF2HTIy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/P9pRF2HTIy<\/a><\/p>\n — Giovanni Colantonio (@MarioPrime) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MarioPrime\/status\/1719398305526861961?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">October 31, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n But perhaps nothing is sadder than the loss of "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MarioPrime\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">one user<\/a>‘s “most treasured joke,” in which he posted to a Circle audience consisting only of Tony Hawk, because you could add people who didn’t follow you to your Circle. And they could not remove themselves.<\/p>\n Some users have expressed concern that their private musings would be made public, now that Circles are no longer. So far, this doesn’t seem to be the case, though you’re able to view your own Circle tweets on your profile. But on X, who knows when something will break, so if you have anything salacious up, it might be worth deleting.<\/p>\n It’s not clear why "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/21\/x-is-shutting-down-its-circle-feature-in-october\/\">X is sunsetting Circles<\/a> — perhaps it will come back as a paid benefit, like another beloved feature, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/15\/x-formerly-twitter-makes-x-pro-formerly-tweetdeck-a-subscriber-only-product\/\">TweetDeck<\/a> (now called X Pro). But users will understandably be annoyed if they have to pay money to X to regain features they used to have for free.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"i0QNe6bERD\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/10\/twitter-circle-bug-not-private\/\">Twitter Circle tweets are not that private anymore<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n ndered":"SBF\u2019s defense puts forth a 35-minute last-ditch effort to show his goodwill"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "featured__span-first-words\">As Sam Bankman-Fried<\/span> took the stand for the last time in his trial for fraud and money laundering, his main lawyer, Mark Cohen, returned to question him on a number of themes that prosecutors touched on in the past few days. But this time, he took a different approach, presenting the defendant as a person who was acting in good faith.<\/p>\n \u201cWe lived and died by having a better product than competitors,\u201d Bankman-Fried said of his "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/11\/ftx-files-for-bankruptcy-ceo-sam-bankman-fried-steps-down\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">now-bankrupt crypto exchange<\/a>, FTX. Bankman-Fried owned majority stakes in both FTX and its sister trading firm, Alameda Research, but insisted he wanted the best for both.<\/p>\n Bankman-Fried has been "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/sam-bankman-fried-takes-the-stand\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">testifying since Thursday afternoon<\/a>, and the prosecution has grilled him for the past few days as "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/sam-bankman-fried-ftx-cross-examination\/\">part of their cross-examination<\/a>. On Tuesday, when the defense lawyers returned to reexamine him, he was swaying slightly on the stand, shoulders drawn down and forward. He spoke softly, but was more talkative than earlier in the day and on Monday when he was being questioned.<\/p>\n Contrary to the picture prosecutors tried to paint, Bankman-Fried insisted that he was not involved in the day-to-day trading operations of Alameda or its \u201ccore operations,\u201d but instead emphasized his concern for its leadership at the time, saying he wanted to be involved in many of its venture investments, decisions on hedging, and other areas.

Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2622595,"date":"2023-10-31T12:58:39","date_gmt":"2023-10-31T19:58:39","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2622595"},"modified":"2023-10-31T14:05:51","modified_gmt":"2023-10-31T21:05:51","slug":"twitter-circle-gone","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/31\/twitter-circle-gone\/","title":{"rendered":"So long, Twitter Circles"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">If tic-tac-toe has taught us anything, it’s that Xs and circles cannot peacefully coexist.<\/p>\n X, the app formerly known as Twitter, has shut down the Circles feature, which allowed users to post to a small, exclusive audience. Like an Instagram Close Friends story, Circles — n\u00e9e Twitter Circles — offered a more intimate social media experience. In other words, you could overshare about your life to an audience of friends only, rather than the whole internet. And isn’t one of the greatest joys of the internet to emotionally shitpost without worrying about the consequences?<\/p>\n But, as the whims of the Circle reminded us, nothing we say on the internet is ever actually free from consequence. The feature worked almost all of the time. Almost. And anything less than 100% efficacy is not ideal for a feature that people used to share private thoughts with trusted friends.<\/p>\n As early as February, some users reported that their Circle tweets were "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/03\/twitter-circle-glitches-have-users-worried-about-privacy\/\">reaching a wider audience<\/a> than they were supposed to. These glitches showed up "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/10\/twitter-circle-bug-not-private\/\">again in April<\/a>, and X (then known as Twitter) "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/05\/twitter-confirms-circle-tweets-temporarily-were-not-private\/\">apologized<\/a> for the error in May, marking a rare moment of transparency for the company.<\/p>\n Even when Circle tweets were truly private, they often appeared not to be — the green banner denoting it as a Circle post only appeared some of the time (I had received some paranoid texts from friends who wondered if I knew I had posted about [redacted] on main, but nope, this was just the glitchy old bird app playing tricks on us).<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n "twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n "en\" dir=\"ltr\">I can't believe this website is going to take away my most treasured joke: my Twitter circle that only contains Tony Hawk.
"https:\/\/t.co\/P9pRF2HTIy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/P9pRF2HTIy<\/a><\/p>\n — Giovanni Colantonio (@MarioPrime) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MarioPrime\/status\/1719398305526861961?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">October 31, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n But perhaps nothing is sadder than the loss of "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MarioPrime\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">one user<\/a>‘s “most treasured joke,” in which he posted to a Circle audience consisting only of Tony Hawk, because you could add people who didn’t follow you to your Circle. And they could not remove themselves.<\/p>\n Some users have expressed concern that their private musings would be made public, now that Circles are no longer. So far, this doesn’t seem to be the case, though you’re able to view your own Circle tweets on your profile. But on X, who knows when something will break, so if you have anything salacious up, it might be worth deleting.<\/p>\n It’s not clear why "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/21\/x-is-shutting-down-its-circle-feature-in-october\/\">X is sunsetting Circles<\/a> — perhaps it will come back as a paid benefit, like another beloved feature, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/15\/x-formerly-twitter-makes-x-pro-formerly-tweetdeck-a-subscriber-only-product\/\">TweetDeck<\/a> (now called X Pro). But users will understandably be annoyed if they have to pay money to X to regain features they used to have for free.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"i0QNe6bERD\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/10\/twitter-circle-bug-not-private\/\">Twitter Circle tweets are not that private anymore<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n uation-tank-56-in-one-year\/","title":{"rendered":"Why did Twitter (X)’s valuation tank 56% in one year?"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">The company formerly known as Twitter, X is valuing itself at $19 billion, per internal documents obtained by "https:\/\/fortune.com\/2023\/10\/30\/x-formerly-twitter-valued-19-billion-employee-stock-plan\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Fortune<\/a>. When Elon Musk bought the company "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/elon-musk-twitter-everything-you-need-to-know\/\">one year ago this week<\/a>, he paid about $44 billion for the microblogging platform, or $54.20 per share.<\/p>\n This internal valuation marks about a 56% decrease in X’s value over the last 12 months, which doesn’t look too good.
"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/01\/twitter-imposes-limits-on-the-number-of-tweets-users-can-read-amid-extended-outage\/\">There<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/06\/twitter-threatens-to-sue-meta-over-its-new-threads-app\/\">are<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/13\/twitter-admits-to-having-a-verified-spammer-problem-with-announcement-of-new-dm-settings\/\">certainly<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/24\/twitter-has-officially-changed-its-logo-to-x\/\">many<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/18\/musk-says-xs-block-feature-is-going-away\/\">explanations<\/a> as to why Twitter’s value has been halved, like how the platform has spent the last year "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/24\/twitter-has-officially-changed-its-logo-to-x\/\">killing global brand awareness<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/15\/twitter-just-banned-a-wave-of-prominent-journalists-with-no-explanation\/#:~:text=On%20Thursday%20evening%2C%20Twitter%20suspended,took%20over%20at%20the%20company.\"> deplatforming journalists<\/a>\u00a0and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/31\/celebrity-blue-check-twitter-verification\/\">aiding impersonation<\/a>. Still, one number rarely tells the whole story of a company, especially when "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/12\/turns-out-most-unicorns-today-are-more-myth-than-reality\/\">company valuations<\/a> can be so "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/10\/the-art-of-vc-startup-valuations-is-a-forgery\/\">arbitrary<\/a>. Depending on who is calculating a company’s valuation — a venture capitalist, a government auditor or an egotistical billionaire — the resulting number can vary drastically. Fidelity, for example, has "https:\/\/www.axios.com\/2023\/10\/29\/fidelity-twitter-x-value-elon-musk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">marked down<\/a> its investment in X by 65%.<\/p>\n The company, which was taken private with Musk’s purchase, is now offering employees restricted stock units (RSUs) at a share price of $45. When private companies offer stock-like compensation options, the IRS advises companies to use a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/20\/what-is-409a-valuation-stripe-instacart\/\"> 409A valuation<\/a>, an independent assessment of how much a company is worth. But these valuations tend to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/20\/what-is-409a-valuation-stripe-instacart\/\">skew more conservative<\/a> than a valuation inferred via new venture funding, for example.<\/p>\n Because of this, it’s not uncommon to see companies’ valuations get slashed after a new 409A appraisal. Last year, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/14\/stripe-fintech-payments-valuation-cut-28\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/14\/stripe-fintech-payments-valuation-cut-28\/\">Stripe<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/25\/as-instacart-looks-to-cut-its-valuation-will-it-kick-off-a-trend\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/25\/as-instacart-looks-to-cut-its-valuation-will-it-kick-off-a-trend\/\">Instacart<\/a> saw their valuations cut by 28% and 38%, respectively.<\/p>\n EquityZen, a company that expands access to private markets investing, has observed these trends consistently among private tech companies.<\/p>\n “At EquityZen, we’ve seen shares trading in private pre-IPO tech companies at an average discount of 49% to the last funding round,” Phil Haslett, founder and CSO of EquityZen, told TechCrunch. Haslett doesn’t see X’s valuation drop as a surprise, though he says the velocity of this drop — just one year — “does raise some concerns.”<\/p>\n Haslett added that a company’s common stock (or, the kind of equity compensation offered to employees) can also be priced at a discount, since the company isn’t public.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n “Since there’s no active liquid market for shares, the company can make an argument that common stock is worth less than the $44 billion price tag,” Haslett told TechCrunch. “This actually benefits employees: they’ll likely get more stock (or at least, stock options with a lower strike price).”<\/p>\n It can be seen as a win-win for both executives and employees when their company gets a deflated 409A valuation, because it makes it less expensive to grant employees stock options. It also "https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/startup-founders-embrace-409a-cuts-to-gain-recruiting-edge\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">makes it easier<\/a> to recruit talent.<\/p>\n “409A valuation sets the tax basis for stock options,” Alex Ross, founder and CEO of the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/27\/greg-an-app-for-plant-lovers-grows-5-4-million-in-seed-funding\/\">plant care app Greg<\/a>, told TechCrunch. As the head of a private startup, he solicits a new 409A valuation about once a year. “At a $19B valuation, Twitter employees pay less in taxes when exercising options than at a $40B valuation.”<\/p>\n But even if this may benefit employees in the short-term, the platform will still need to recoup its lost value if its “ "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/16\/musk-poses-workers-with-a-choice-quit-twitter-or-prepare-to-get-hardcore\/\">hardcore<\/a>” employees will get an eventual windfall.<\/p>\n So, is it worrisome that X is touting a $19 billion valuation? Yeah, but it may not be that alarming to those who work there.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"IWuEvpruZE\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/20\/what-is-409a-valuation-stripe-instacart\/\">WTF is a 409A?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“WTF is a 409A?” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/20\/what-is-409a-valuation-stripe-instacart\/embed\/#?secret=132bLe5cKo#?secret=IWuEvpruZE\" data-secret=\"IWuEvpruZE\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The company formerly known as Twitter, X is valuing itself at $19 billion, per internal documents obtained by Fortune. When Elon Musk bought the company one year ago this week, he paid about $44 billion for the microblogging platform, or $54.20 per share. This internal valuation marks about a 56% decrease in X’s value over […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574468,"featured_media":2573678,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"9bf49530-5167-339d-bbcc-40b1e9f8fd40","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-30T21:55:41Z","apple_news_api_id":"0cf8c07d-afa6-4334-8d0d-ffe812b12b2e","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-30T22:14:15Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/ADPjAfa-mQzSNDf_oErErLg","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577055593],"tags":[37303,1244446,599182,37820,1700],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n Why did Twitter (X)'s valuation tank 56% in one year? | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"The company formerly known as Twitter, X is valuing itself at $19 billion, per internal documents obtained by Fortune. name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1700"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1700"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2548803,"date":"2023-10-27T10:15:09","date_gmt":"2023-10-27T17:15:09","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2548803"},"modified":"2023-10-27T11:08:42","modified_gmt":"2023-10-27T18:08:42","slug":"elon-musk-twitter-everything-you-need-to-know","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/elon-musk-twitter-everything-you-need-to-know\/","title":{"rendered":"Elon Musk’s Twitter a year later: Everything you need to know"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Welcome to Elon Musk\u2019s Twitter ( "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/25\/twitter-changes-its-official-handle-to-x\/\">now X<\/a>), where the rules are "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/15\/twitter-just-banned-a-wave-of-prominent-journalists-with-no-explanation\/\">made up<\/a> and the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/03\/twitters-new-label-makes-it-hard-to-differentiate-between-legacy-and-paid-verified-accounts\/\">check marks<\/a> don\u2019t matter.<\/p>\n The Tesla and SpaceX CEO announced his bid to buy Twitter in April 2022, zealously driven to rid the platform of spam bots and protect free speech; now, it\u2019s the one-year anniversary since he made his dramatic entrance to the company in October 2022, and the platform has changed so much that even its name is different.<\/p>\n \u201cThis is just my strong, intuitive sense that having a public platform that is maximally trusted and broadly inclusive is extremely important to the future of civilization,\u201d Musk "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/14\/elon-musk-buying-twitter-ted-talk\/\">said<\/a> at a TED conference on the day he made his offer. \u201cI don\u2019t care about the economics at all.\u201d<\/p>\n Even for one of the richest men in the world, $44 billion is a lot of money to cough up to buy a middling social platform. Despite his fervent declarations about expanding \u201cthe scope and scale of consciousness\u201d through public discourse, the billionaire got cold feet. A month later in May, he tried to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/elon-musk-twitter-spam\/\">kill the deal<\/a>, claiming that Twitter had more bots than its public filings let on. After a truly chaotic legal discovery process, which even included some "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/29\/elon-musk-texts-discovery-twitter\/\">embarrassing texts<\/a>, Musk was forced to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/27\/elon-musk-bought-twitter\/\">seal the deal<\/a>. By October, the platform was his.<\/p>\n Since Musk bought Twitter and took the company private, the news around the microblogging platform has been a whirlwind, rife with verification chaos, API access shakeups, ban reversals, staggering layoffs, and most notably, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/24\/twitter-has-officially-changed-its-logo-to-x\/\">rebranding to X<\/a>.<\/p>\n Musk also transitioned from his role as Twitter\/X CEO to serving as its executive chair and CTO. It was announced on May 12 that "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/12\/elon-musk-appoints-new-twitter-ceo-nbcus-linda-yaccarino\/\">Linda Yaccarino will step in as the next X CEO<\/a>. Yaccarino left her role as chairman of Global Advertising & Partnerships at NBCU.<\/p>\n As X enters year two of Musk\u2019s ownership, here\u2019s a comprehensive timeline of everything that\u2019s happened since Elon "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/26\/elon-musk-twitter-hq-deal\/\"> let that sink in<\/a>.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Here\u2019s a complete timeline of what\u2019s going down at X, starting with the most recent news:<\/h2>\n October 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/x-starts-experimenting-with-a-1-per-year-fee-for-new-users\/\">X tests charging $1 per year in select markets<\/a><\/h3>\n \u201cThis new test was developed to bolster our already successful efforts to reduce spam, manipulation of our platform, and bot activity while balancing platform accessibility with the small fee amount. It is not a profit driver,\u201d the company said.<\/p>\n The company plans to use "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/18\/x-plans-to-use-payment-phone-and-id-verification-to-stop-bots-in-addition-to-the-new-1-yr-fee\/\">payment, phone and ID verification to stop bots<\/a>.<\/p>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">Starting today, we’re testing a new program (Not A Bot) in New Zealand and the Philippines. New, unverified accounts will be required to sign up for a $1 annual subscription to be able to post & interact with other posts. Within this test, existing users are not affected.<\/p>\n This\u2026<\/p>\n \u2014 Support (@Support) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/Support\/status\/1714429406192582896?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">October 17, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/one-year-post-acquisition-x-traffic-and-monthly-active-users-are-in-decline-report-claims\/\">A new report claims X traffic and monthly active users are down<\/a><\/h3>\n According to\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.similarweb.com\/blog\/insights\/social-media-news\/x-twitter-musk\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.similarweb.com\/blog\/insights\/social-media-news\/x-twitter-musk\/\">data from market intelligence firm Similarweb<\/a>, X\u2019s global site traffic was down 14% YoY in September. U.S. traffic was down by 19%. Performance had also declined 17.8% YoY on mobile devices in the U.S., based on monthly active users on iOS and Android.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/13\/x-communities-start-to-look-more-like-facebook-groups-with-new-member-vetting-feature\/\">X now requires users to answer a question before joining private Communities\u00a0<\/a><\/h3>\n Admins of private Communities on X can now require users to answer a question when they request to join, along with agreeing to the group\u2019s rules. The new feature could help admins and moderators decide who should be able to join and offer some protection against spammers and bots.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/12\/after-delays-x-updates-community-notes-fact-checks-to-improve-speed-and-distribution\/\">X updates Community Notes<\/a><\/h3>\n A series of updates were made to Community Notes after the fact-checking system took "https:\/\/www.nbcnews.com\/tech\/misinformation\/elon-musk-x-fact-check-israel-misinformation-rcna119658\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> multiple days to correct misinformation<\/a> related to the Israel-Hamas war. The "https:\/\/twitter.com\/CommunityNotes\/status\/1712227978682200565\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">changes<\/a> include:<\/p>\n \n X CEO Linda Yaccarino promised Community Notes would “appear more quickly on X”<\/li>\n Note previews are now supported on both Android and the web, with support \u201ccoming soon\u201d to iOS<\/li>\n Improved media matching<\/li>\n Notifications will send to users who Liked, Reposted or Replied to a post that later received a note<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/10\/x-changes-its-public-interest-policy-to-redefine-newsworthiness-of-posts\/\">X changes its “Public interest expectations”<\/a><\/h3>\n X\/Twitter removed the requirement of having at least 100,000 followers for posts to be newsworthy. Prior to the policy change, only verified accounts would be considered for newsworthy posts. However, now that X allows\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/twitters-legacy-blue-checkmark-era-is-officially-over\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/twitters-legacy-blue-checkmark-era-is-officially-over\/\">people to get verified by paying for a subscription<\/a>, the new version of the policy says posts only by \u201ca high-profile account\u201d counts as newsworthy posts.<\/p>\n However, the updated page doesn\u2019t give details on what kind of accounts are considered \u201chigh-profile.\u201d<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/09\/xs-new-control-lets-only-verified-accounts-reply-to-a-post\/\">X can now limit replies to verified users<\/a><\/h3>\n The new control is not restricted to paid\/premium accounts. Users who don\u2019t pay for X Premium can also choose to not let non-verified users reply to their posts.<\/p>\n The "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/11\/twitter-now-lets-everyone-limit-replies-to-their-tweets\/\">feature originally limited replies<\/a> to either “Accounts you follow” or “Only accounts you mention” in 2020, but users could only choose this setting before posting a tweet. In 2021, they "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/13\/twitter-change-who-can-reply\/\">updated the feature<\/a> to allow users to control replies after a tweet was published.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/06\/x-to-test-three-tiers-of-its-premium-service-ceo-says-code-shows-one-tier-may-be-ad-free\/\">X to test its three premium tiers <\/a><\/h3>\n X CEO Linda Yaccarino discussed the plan in a briefing to X debt holders on October 5th.<\/p>\n It\u2019s not clear when the three-tier subscription plan would go live,\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/aaronp613\/status\/1710060481296105874\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/aaronp613\/status\/1710060481296105874\">but references found in the X app\u2019s code by @aaronp613<\/a>\u00a0reference a \u201cPremium Basic,\u201d \u201cPremium Standard\u201d and \u201cPremium Plus\u201d plan, which have full ads, half the ads or no ads, respectively.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/05\/x-cuts-headlines-from-link-previews-as-musk-wants-users-posting-directly-on-the-platform\/\">X is cutting headlines from link previews<\/a><\/h3>\n Now you will only be able to see an image with the domain name of the link on the bottom left, which is easy to miss. The change is part of Musk\u2019s efforts to get users to post \u201clong-form content\u201d directly on the platform rather than encouraging users to click out of the platform with link cards.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/02\/elon-musks-x-corp-faces-trademark-lawsuit-from-social-media-ad-agency\/\">X Corp. faces a trademark lawsuit<\/a><\/h3>\n Trademark attorney "https:\/\/www.gerbenlaw.com\/about\/josh-gerben\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.gerbenlaw.com\/about\/josh-gerben\/\">\u00a0Josh Gerben<\/a> and his firm are representing what seems to be the first client to sue X over its trademark \u2014 a Florida-based social media ad agency, "https:\/\/www.xsocialmedia.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.xsocialmedia.com\/\"> X Social Media.<\/a><\/p>\n The\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-corp-trademark-lawsuit.pdf\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-corp-trademark-lawsuit.pdf\">complaint<\/a>, which was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida,\u00a0states that X Social Media, LLC\u00a0 \u201chas continuously used the X Social Media Mark in commerce since at least early 2016,\u201d<\/em>\u00a0and has significantly invested in marketplace awareness, which included developing a distinctive \u201cX\u201d mark that\u2019s associated with its social media advertising services.<\/p>\n September 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/21\/x-is-shutting-down-its-circle-feature-in-october\/\">X is shutting down its circle feature<\/a><\/h3>\n \u201cX is deprecating Circles as of Oct 31st, 2023. After this date, you will not be able to create new posts that are limited to your Circle, nor will you be able to add people to your Circle. You will, however, be able to remove people from your Circle, by unfollowing them as described below,\u201d X said on\u00a0 "https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/using-x\/twitter-circle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/using-x\/twitter-circle\">its support page<\/a>.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/25\/x-will-make-audio-and-video-calls-a-premium-subscriber-only-feature\/\">Audio and video calls will be available to premium subscribers<\/a><\/h3>\n New code in the X app reveals that both audio and video calls will be supported. However, the feature will only be available to those with an X Premium membership, it appears. The new findings were uncovered by tech veteran- "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/09\/messina-joins-ride-home-funds-new-15m-ai-vehicle-backed-by-andreessen-dixon-crowley\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/09\/messina-joins-ride-home-funds-new-15m-ai-vehicle-backed-by-andreessen-dixon-crowley\/\">turned-investor<\/a>\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@chris\/post\/Cxd2ezwyRRn\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@chris\/post\/Cxd2ezwyRRn\">Chris Messina<\/a>\u00a0inside the X app\u2019s code.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/18\/elon-musk-says-x-will-charge-users-a-small-monthly-payment-to-use-its-service\/\">X may no longer be a free site<\/a><\/h3>\n In a live-streamed\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/netanyahu\/status\/1703806204894498966\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/netanyahu\/status\/1703806204894498966\">conversation<\/a> with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, X Owner Elon Musk said the company was \u201cmoving to a small monthly payment\u201d for the use of the platform. He suggested that such a change would be necessary to deal with the problem of bots.<\/p>\n Musk didn\u2019t confirm what the new subscription payment would cost, but described it as a \u201csmall amount of money.\u201d<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/15\/x-launches-account-verification-based-on-government-id\/\">X launches account verification<\/a><\/h3>\n X has launched government ID-based account verification via a partnership with Israel-based Au10tix for paid users to prevent impersonation and give them benefits such as \u201cprioritized support.\u201d The pop-up for ID verification indicates that the Au10tix could store this data for up to 30 days.<\/p>\n "article__title-wrapper\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/08\/x-formerly-twitter-caught-running-unlabeled-ads-in-users-following-feeds\/\">X caught running unlabeled ads in users\u2019 Following feeds<\/a><\/h3>\n \n "speakable-summary\">While scrolling the Following feed on a Mac using the Chrome web browser, TechCrunch encountered a handful of unlabeled ads amid other posts from people we follow, as well as other ads that did\u00a0properly display the \u201cAd\u201d label at the top right of the post.<\/p>\n Because many of X\u2019s ads are still labeled, this makes the unlabeled ones even harder to spot.<\/p>\n It\u2019s unclear if the issue is a glitch with X\u2019s advertising platform or a deliberate change.<\/p>\n<\/div>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/08\/x-updates-its-terms-to-ban-crawling-and-scraping\/\">X bans scraping and crawling<\/a><\/h3>\n The\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/tos\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/tos\">new terms<\/a>, which are effective from September 29, ban any kind of scraping or crawling without \u201cprior written consent.\u201d<\/p>\n NOTE: crawling or scraping the Services in any form, for any purpose without our prior written consent is expressly prohibited.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n The previous version of the terms allowed crawling in accordance with robots.txt.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/06\/x-launches-community-notes-for-videos\/\">Community Notes is now available for videos on X<\/a><\/h3>\n Community Notes is an existing program for crowdsourced moderation. X announced that notes by contributors attached to a video will show up in all posts with that video.<\/p>\n August 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/31\/x-plans-to-collect-users-biometric-data-along-with-education-and-job-history\/\">X will begin collecting user’s biometric data along with education and job history on September 29<\/a><\/h3>\n \u201cBased on your consent, we may collect and use your biometric information for safety, security, and identification purposes,\u201d "https:\/\/twitter.com\/en\/privacy#x-privacy-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the updated policy reads<\/a>. X hasn\u2019t specified what it means by biometric information, but it is usually used to describe a person\u2019s physical characteristics, such as their face or fingerprints. X also hasn\u2019t provided details on how it plans to collect it.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/31\/x-formerly-twitter-is-now-letting-paid-users-hide-their-likes\/\">X allows paid users to hide their likes<\/a><\/h3>\n Paid users on X now have a setting under profile customization that lets them hide the Likes tab. The move comes after rival social networks "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/06\/threads-app-is-rolling-out-to-a-way-to-see-your-liked-posts\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Threads<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/27\/after-threads-bluesky-also-adds-a-way-to-see-your-own-likes\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bluesky<\/a> rolled out the ability for users to see their own likes.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/30\/x-to-allow-paid-political-ads-lifting-twitters-earlier-ban\/\">X confirms it’s lifting the ban on political ads<\/a><\/h3>\n X "https:\/\/blog.twitter.com\/en_us\/topics\/company\/2023\/supporting-peoples-right-to-accurate-and-safe-political-discourse-on-x\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/blog.twitter.com\/en_us\/topics\/company\/2023\/supporting-peoples-right-to-accurate-and-safe-political-discourse-on-x\">confirmed<\/a>\u00a0it\u2019s lifting its ban on paid political ads \u2014 a move it\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/03\/twitter-is-set-to-reverse-the-political-ad-ban-to-bolster-up-its-revenue\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/03\/twitter-is-set-to-reverse-the-political-ad-ban-to-bolster-up-its-revenue\/\">committed to earlier this year<\/a>, shortly after Elon Musk took over the social network previously known as Twitter. The company had originally banned these ads "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/11\/15\/twitter-makes-its-political-ad-ban-official\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/11\/15\/twitter-makes-its-political-ad-ban-official\/\">in 2019<\/a> under then-CEO Jack Dorsey\u2019s management.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/24\/x-tries-to-lure-back-advertisers-with-new-250-ad-credit\/\">X lures advertisers with a $250 ad credit<\/a><\/h3>\n The company\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/XBusiness\/status\/1694425406592422200\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/XBusiness\/status\/1694425406592422200\">announced<\/a>\u00a0it would offer a one-time ad credit of $250 to select businesses when they spend $1,000 or more on new ad campaigns over the next 30 days.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/23\/x-changes-its-api-to-retire-legacy-tiers-and-endpoints\/\">X makes changes to retire some of the legacy API endpoints<\/a><\/h3>\n The company said in\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/API\/status\/1693760591503266165\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/API\/status\/1693760591503266165\">a post<\/a> that it\u2019s discontinuing some of the endpoints while migrating others to the new v2 API. X also said that it is retiring the legacy Essential and Elevated tiers, and customers using them will need to move to any of the new tiers.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/22\/x-is-planning-to-hide-headlines-from-news-links-for-improved-aesthetics\/\">X plans to hide headlines from news links<\/a><\/h3>\n "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1693843680904216619?\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Musk confirmed<\/a> the move to roll out a new way to display news links without any headline or description in a post, saying the move was coming \u201cdirectly\u201d from him. The change would \u201cgreatly improve the aesthetics,\u201d he said.<\/p>\n As of right now, a Twitter card for a news article shows the headline and summary text along with the header image in the preview card of a post. If the proposed change comes through, X will only show the image with a link in a post. That means if a publication or a blog doesn\u2019t post any accompanying text with the link, users will only see the link and the image for that article.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/18\/musk-says-xs-block-feature-is-going-away\/\">Elon Musk says the ‘block’ feature is going away<\/a><\/h3>\n \u201cBlock is going to be deleted as a \u2018feature\u2019, except for DMs,\u201d "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1692558414105186796\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Elon Musk wrote on X<\/a>. \u201cMakes no sense.\u201d The post was a response to a Tesla fan account who asked whether there was any reason to use block instead of mute.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/16\/x-formerly-twitter-now-sorts-posts-like-count-profiles-when-signed-out\/\">X now sorts posts by like counts\u00a0<\/a><\/h3>\n Posts, formerly called tweets, still appear in chronological order on profiles when you\u2019re logged into the social network, but once you log out, they are sorted by performance.<\/p>\n Our tests show that even if you have a pinned post, it won\u2019t appear at the top of your profile feed when logged out, which defeats the point of a pinned post.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/15\/paid-users-of-x-formerly-twitter-gets-a-new-tab-to-highlight-their-posts\/\">X rolls out a new ‘Highlights’ tab for paid users<\/a><\/h3>\n X began rolling out the new \u2018Highlights\u2019 tab to some subscribers in mid August. However, the social network was delayed in implementing the new rule by a few days.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/10\/x-formerly-twitter-lowers-requirements-for-its-ad-revenue-sharing-program\/\">X lowers requirements for its creator payout program<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">The company said that creators who have garnered 5 million impressions in the last three months will be eligible for ad revenue sharing. Users still need to be verified and must have at least 500 followers to qualify for payouts.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/10\/ceo-says-x-formerly-twitter-is-close-to-break-even\/\">X CEO claims the company formerly known as Twitter is almost breaking even<\/a><\/h3>\n \u201cI\u2019ve been at the company eight weeks,\u201d Yaccarino said in her first broadcast interview since taking on her new role. \u201cThe operational run rate right now\u2026 we\u2019re pretty close to break even.\u201d<\/p>\n \u201cOur data licensing and API with X is an incredible business. Now, X is testing sensitivity settings, powered by machine learning, that let advertisers choose their thresholds for the kinds of content they want their ads to appear around \u2014 and according to a tweet from X owner Elon Musk, advertisers can buy these less desirable, \u201crelaxed\u201d sensitivity ad slots for less.<\/p>\n Brands can reduce adjacency to gore, excessive profanity and obscenity, targeted hate speech, sexual content, drugs and spam.\u00a0Soon, X will add its \u201crelaxed\u201d setting, which offers cheaper advertising opportunities while only filtering for targeted hate speech and explicit sexual content.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/08\/xs-takeover-of-music-handle-hints-toward-possible-music-plans\/\">X takes over @music handle, hinting at future music plans<\/a><\/h3>\n The @music account was originally operated for 16 years by software developer Jeremy Vaught, who grew the @music handle to roughly half a million followers. "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1684804492431175680?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Musk hinted at the change a week prior<\/a>, adding that XPro will come with a “wide range of psy op plugins.” There are no details about what kind of plug-ins those might be.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/01\/x-twitter-paid-users-hide-checkmarks\/\">X now allows paid users to hide their checkmarks<\/a><\/h3>\n Paid verification was introduced last year with the Twitter Blue relaunch. The company didn\u2019t give any further details about those placeholders.<\/p>\n July 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/31\/how-to-change-back-to-the-old-twitter-app-icon-on-ios\/\">Want to change back to the old Twitter app icon on iOS? Here’s how:<\/a><\/h3>\n \n On your iPhone, navigate to the Shortcuts app. If you have a newer iPhone, this should be pre-installed, but if not, you can find it in the App Store. If your iPhone is running on iOS 12.0 or higher, you\u2019re good to go.<\/li>\n From the main Shortcuts screen on the Shortcuts app, you\u2019re going to tap \u201cAll Shortcuts.\u201d<\/li>\n Hit the blue plus sign in the top-right corner of your screen to set up a new Shortcut.<\/li>\n You should see a suggested action of \u201cOpen App\u201d to build your new shortcut. Tap that.<\/li>\n Now, you\u2019ll be prompted to set up a new \u201cOpen App\u201d shortcut. Next to where it says \u201cOpen,\u201d click on \u201cApp\u201d to search for the X app. Select that.<\/li>\n Once you\u2019ve selected the \u201cX\u201d app, tap the share icon on the navigation bar at the bottom of your screen. This will bring up another menu, where you can select \u201cAdd to Home Screen.\u201d<\/li>\n Go ahead and type in Twitter instead of \u201cOpen App.\u201d Then, tap the small Shortcut icon next to where you typed in Twitter.<\/li>\n Here, you can upload an image of the Twitter logo. "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/20\/twitter-prepping-job-listings-feature-verified-organizations\/\">Twitter preps a job listing feature\u00a0<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter hasn\u2019t officially
