bios. The job listings take applicants directly to the company\u2019s website, where they can learn more about the position and submit an application.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/18\/twitter-to-support-long-form-articles-with-mixed-media-elon-musk-confirms\/\">Twitter Notes is back…kinda<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">Twitter Notes, the feature that "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/06\/22\/twitter-officially-rolls-out-its-long-form-content-notes-feature\/\">allows Twitter users to publish long-form content<\/a>, appears to be back on track, according to a "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1681346514742919170\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">post<\/a> from Twitter owner Elon Musk on Tuesday. Musk confirmed the company\u2019s plans in response to a user\u2019s tweet which claimed the Twitter Notes project had recently been rebranded as \u201cArticles.\u201d<\/p>\n On Tuesday, July 18, user @FaustoChou tweeted that Notes had been renamed to Articles, signaling perhaps renewed development efforts on Twitter\u2019s part. His screenshot showed the Notes interface, looking much like it did before, as well as other unlaunched features, like Twitter Coins.
"https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1681346514742919170?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Musk replied to the tweet<\/a>, confirming Twitter\u2019s plans.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/13\/twitter-starts-sharing-ad-revenue-with-verified-creators\/\">Twitter shares ad revenue with verified creators<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">Twitter will now pay creators for a share of the ad revenue earned from ads served in the replies to their posts. Twitter Blue subscribers who have earned more than 5 million tweet impressions each month for the last 3 months are eligible to join the creator payouts.<\/p>\n According to Elon Musk, the first round of creator payouts will total "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1667314848856948736?\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1667314848856948736?\">\u00a0$5 million<\/a>, and will be\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1679532945038798848\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1679532945038798848\">cumulative<\/a>\u00a0from the month of February onward. These payouts will be delivered via Stripe.<\/p>\n Despite the program\u2019s significant payouts, some creators weren\u2019t happy \u2014 and took their complaints to Twitter owner Elon Musk. In a series of tweets, Musk addressed creators\u2019 concerns over things like the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/17\/twitter-tweaks-its-new-revenue-sharing-policy-for-creators-to-expand-access-increase-rate-limits\/\">types of accounts that were eligible for monetization, rate limits and other issues<\/a>.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/13\/twitter-admits-to-having-a-verified-spammer-problem-with-announcement-of-new-dm-settings\/\">With the announcement of new DM settings, Twitter admits to having a Verified spammer issue<\/a><\/h3>\n "https:\/\/twitter.com\/twittersupport\/status\/1679529814212894723\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Starting \u201cas soon as\u201d July 14<\/a>, Twitter will introduce a new messages setting aimed at reducing spam in DMs by moving messages from Verified users you don\u2019t follow back to your \u201cMessage Request\u201d inbox instead of your main inbox. Only messages from people you follow will arrive in your primary inbox going forward. Notably, these changes will also now apply to everyone who has their inboxes open to allow messages from anyone.<\/p>\n Before becoming pay-to-play, Twitter verification indicated a person was a public or notable figure of some sort \u2014 like a politician, celebrity, athlete, journalist or other well-known individual. By making the Verified blue checkmark accessible to anyone who purchased it, Twitter diluted the value of verification.<\/p>\n That apparently escalated to the point that people have become bothered by Verified users spamming their main inbox, when they had set it open to receive DMs from the blue-badged crowd. In other words, Twitter has a Verified user spam problem.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/11\/twitter-blocks-links-to-rival-threads-while-ceo-downplays-reports-of-traffic-decline\/\">Twitter blocks links to Threads<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter CEO Linda Yaccarino is pushing back at reports that Twitter traffic is tanking as a result of the July 5\u00a0launch of a new competitor, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/17\/what-is-instagrams-threads-app-all-your-questions-answered\/\">Instagram Threads<\/a>. However, on Monday, July 10, users reported that Twitter seems to be selectively blocking links to Threads.net\u2019s website in Twitter searches, making it more difficult for anyone to surface conversations on Threads or locate users\u2019 profiles.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/06\/twitter-threatens-to-sue-meta-over-its-new-threads-app\/\">Twitter threatens to sue Meta over its new Threads app<\/a><\/h3>\n Less than 24 hours after Threads launched, the Elon Musk-owned company accused Meta of poaching former Twitter employees to create the new platform.<\/p>\n \u201cTwitter intends to strictly enforce its intellectual property rights, and demands that Meta take immediate steps to stop using any Twitter trade secrets or other highly confidential information,\u201d Spiro wrote in the\u00a0 "https:\/\/cdn.sanity.io\/files\/ifn0l6bs\/production\/27109f01431939c8177d408d3c9848c3b46632cd.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/cdn.sanity.io\/files\/ifn0l6bs\/production\/27109f01431939c8177d408d3c9848c3b46632cd.pdf\">letter<\/a>, which Semafor shared online. \u201cTwitter reserves all rights, including, but not limited to, the right to seek both civil remedies and injunctive relief without further notice to prevent any further retention, disclosure, or use of its intellectual property by Meta.\u201d<\/p>\n June 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/03\/twitter-said-only-verified-users-will-be-able-to-access-tweetdeck-after-30-days\/\">Only verified users will be able to access TweetDeck after 30 days from now<\/a><\/h3>\n After swaths of users were unable to\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/03\/tweetdeck-suffers-as-musk-enforces-read-limits-on-twitter\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/03\/tweetdeck-suffers-as-musk-enforces-read-limits-on-twitter\/\">access parts of TweetDeck over the last few days<\/a>, Twitter started rolling out a new version of the web app to users July 3. The company also added that in 30 days, users will have to be verified to access TweetDeck. This means only Twitter Blue subscribers, verified organizations and some folks who have been gifted verification by Twitter will be able to use TweetDeck come August.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/01\/twitter-imposes-limits-on-the-number-of-tweets-users-can-read-amid-extended-outage\/\">Twitter limits the number of tweets users can read in a day<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">Twitter is putting limits to how many tweets its users can read as the social media platform suffers extended outage that has stymied users\u2019 ability to track new posts.<\/p>\n Verified account holders can peruse a maximum of 6,000 posts daily, while unverified users must contend with a drastically reduced limit of 600 posts. Newly registered, unverified users face even tighter restrictions with an allowance of a mere 300 posts per day, according to Elon Musk. (He has since increased the limit to 10,000, 1,000 and 500, respectively.)<\/p>\n These read limits "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/03\/tweetdeck-suffers-as-musk-enforces-read-limits-on-twitter\/\">impacted TweetDeck users<\/a> in particular, reporting major problems including notifications and entire columns failing to load.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/30\/twitter-now-requires-an-account-to-view-tweets\/\">Twitter requires an account to view tweets<\/a><\/h3>\n If you’re not logged into your Twitter account, or don’t have one, and try to view a tweet, you’ll be presented with a sign-in screen. However, days later, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/05\/twitter-silently-removes-login-requirement-for-viewing-tweets\/\">Twitter silently removed the login requirement for viewing tweets<\/a>.<\/p>\n When Twitter started enforcing the login requirement, Musk said that he took these \u201ctemporary\u201d measures to prevent data scraping.<\/p>\n The company hasn\u2019t made any official announcement about allowing users to view links when you aren\u2019t logged in or given any details on what measures it has taken to stop scraping.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/27\/twitter-now-allows-subscribers-to-post-25000-character-long-tweets\/\">Subscribers can now post 25,000-character-long tweets<\/a><\/h3>\n The company made the change to its Twitter Blue page today, indicating the limit. An engineer at Twitter, Prachi Poddar, also announced the change by "https:\/\/twitter.com\/imPrachiPoddar\/status\/1671003918665646081\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">posting a long tweet<\/a>.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/15\/twitter-is-facing-a-250-million-lawsuit-filed-by-major-music-publishers\/\">Twitter faces a $250 million lawsuit filed by major music publishers<\/a><\/h3>\n The National Music Publishers\u2019 Association (NMPA), representing 17 publishers, listed 1,700 songs for which it sent multiple copyright violation notices to Twitter. The "https:\/\/www.courtlistener.com\/docket\/67501703\/concord-music-group-inc-v-x-corp\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.courtlistener.com\/docket\/67501703\/concord-music-group-inc-v-x-corp\/\">lawsuit<\/a>, filed in Federal District Court in Nashville, says that Twitter didn\u2019t take any action against these notices. The publishers\u2019 organization said in the filing that it is seeking fines of up to $150,000 for each violation.<\/p>\n The lawsuit alleged that the social network \u201cfuels its business with countless infringing copies of musical \u2018compositions, violating Publishers\u2019 and others\u2019 exclusive rights under copyright law.\u201d It added that, unlike its competitors TikTok and Instagram, Twitter hasn\u2019t struck a music licensing deal for the use of copyrighted music.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/14\/twitter-is-being-evicted-from-its-boulder-office-over-unpaid-rent\/\">Twitter is being evicted from its Boulder office<\/a><\/h3>\n Court documents show that Twitter owes three months’ rent to its Boulder landlord, and a judge has signed off on evicting the tech giant from that office.<\/p>\n In May the landlord took it to court, and on May 31 the judge issued an order that the sheriff should assist in the eviction of Twitter within the next 49 days \u2014 i.e. before the end of July. The case number is 2023CV30342 in Boulder District Court.<\/p>\n As many as 300 employees once worked in Twitter\u2019s Boulder offices, but between layoffs, other firings, and resignations, it is probably less than half of that now.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/07\/twitter-increases-window-to-edit-tweets-to-one-hour-for-blue-subscribers\/\">Window to edit tweets is increased to one hour for Blue subscribers<\/a><\/h3>\n The time limit to edit tweets has increased from 30 minutes to one hour for Blue subscribers, giving users a bigger window to change their tweets and correct any typos.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/06\/linda-yaccarino-is-officially-on-the-job-as-twitter-ceo\/\">Linda Yaccarino is officially Twitter CEO<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter CEO Linda takeover.<\/p>\n May 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/31\/twitter-launches-community-notes-for-images\/\">Twitter launched Community Notes for images in posts<\/a><\/h3>\n The latest While earlier longer video upload was only possible from the web, now it\u2019s also possible through the iOS app. Despite these changes, the maximum quality for upload still remains 1080p.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/12\/elon-musk-appoints-new-twitter-ceo-nbcus-linda-yaccarino\/\">The rumors are confirmed: NBCU’s leader Linda Yaccarino as the next CEO of Twitter<\/a><\/h3>\n Musk confirmed Yaccarino\u2019s new role in a tweet this morning (May 12), a day after he announced that he had completed his search for a new CEO.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/11\/elon-musk-says-he-has-found-a-new-ceo-for-twitter\/\">Elon Musk tweets that he has found a new CEO\u00a0<\/a><\/h3>\n \u201cExcited to announce that I\u2019ve a new CEO for X\/Twitter,\u201d Musk wrote in a tweet on May 11. \u201cShe will be starting in ~6 weeks! TechCrunch "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/10\/twitter-circle-bug-not-private\/\">reported the glitch<\/a> in early April, but the platform confirmed the issue May 5 in an email sent to Twitter Circle users.<\/p>\n \u201cIn April 2023, a security incident may have allowed users outside of your Twitter Circle to see tweets that should have otherwise been limited to the Circle to which you were posting,\u201d the email said. Twitter claims that the bug has now been fixed, and that the team knows what caused it.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/03\/twitter-makes-it-api-free-for-public-announcement-accounts\/\">Twitter makes its API free for public announcement accounts\u00a0<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter announced on May 2 that it is making its API free for verified government or public-owned services posting about public utility alerts such as weather alerts, transportation information and emergency warnings. But once you refresh the page it disappears. In fact, it\u2019s unclear whether anyone else can even see your check briefly reappear.<\/p>\n April 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/26\/twitter-disinformation-dsa-risk\/\">EU warns Twitter over disinformation<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">Twitter was confirmed April 25\u00a0as one of "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/25\/europe-names-19-platforms-that-must-report-algorithmic-risks-under-dsa\/\">19 major tech platforms subject to centralized oversight<\/a> by the European Union\u2019s executive starting this fall, when so-called very large online platforms (VLOPs) are expected to be compliant with the Digital Services Act (DSA). But the Commission has not wasted any time warning the\u00a0Elon Musk-owned social network\u00a0that things aren\u2019t looking good for staying on the right side of the incoming law.<\/p>\n In a "https:\/\/twitter.com\/VeraJourova\/status\/1651158784629260288?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1651159180798050305%7Ctwgr%5E55659a9ffe0b6e808049c206fd24680a4140f2c3%7Ctwcon%5Es2_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Ftechcrunch.com%2F2023%2F04%2F26%2Ftwitter-disinformation-dsa-risk%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pair of tweets<\/a>, Vera Jourova, the EU\u2019s values and transparency VP, warned of \u201cyet another negative sign\u201d by Twitter \u2014 accusing the platform under Musk of \u201cnot making digital information space any safer and free from the Kremlin #disinformation & malicious influence\u201d.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/25\/twitter-will-now-show-labels-on-tweets-with-reduced-visiblity\/\">Twitter now shows labels on tweets with reduced visibility<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter said that labels will be shown to both authors and viewers. Usually, these tweets will show text such as \u201cVisibility limited: this Tweet may violate Twitter’s rules against Hateful Conduct.\u201d<\/p>\n The app’s "https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/rules-and-policies\/enforcement-options\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">enforcement policy<\/a>\u00a0says that tweets with such labels will not show up in search results, recommendations or timelines \u2014 those tweets will be hidden in both the \u201cFor You\u201d and \u201cFollowing timelines. Additionally, there will be no ads placed adjacent to posts with reduced visibility.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/24\/twitter-reinstates-blue-verification-mark-for-top-accounts-even-if-they-didnt-pay-for-it\/\">Twitter restored Blue verification mark for top accounts, even if they didn’t pay for Twitter Blue<\/a><\/h3>\n Over the April 21st weekend, multiple top accounts (with more than 1 million followers) got their verification marks back. It\u2019s not clear if the company is applying the same policy to personal accounts.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/21\/twitter-removes-government-funded-news-labels-after-npr-and-other-flubs\/\">Twitter removes ‘government-funded’ news labels<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter has removed \u201cgovernment-funded media\u201d labels on all accounts, from NPR to the Chinese state-affiliated Xinhua News. Lawsuit time.<\/p>\n \u2014 Elon Musk (@elonmusk) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1648784955655192577?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">April 19, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/18\/twitter-removed-deadnaming-misgendering-policy\/\">Twitter quietly removes policy against misgendering trans people<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">Twitter updated its content moderation guidelines regarding hateful content, removing a policy that prohibited the targeted deadnaming or misgendering of transgender people. Enacted in 2018, the policy explicitly stated that it violated Twitter\u2019s rules to repeatedly and purposefully call a transgender person by the wrong name or pronouns.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/17\/twitter-says-it-will-label-tweets-that-violate-its-hate-speech-policy-and-get-downranked-as-a-result\/\">Twitter to label tweets that get downranked for violating its hate speech policy<\/a><\/h3>\n "https:\/\/blog.twitter.com\/en_us\/topics\/product\/2023\/freedom-of-speech-not-reach-an-update-on-our-enforcement-philosophy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter plans<\/a> to \u201csoon\u201d begin adding visible labels on tweets that have been identified as potentially violating its policies, which has impacted their visibility. It did not say when exactly the system would be fully rolled out across its network.<\/p>\n "speakable-summary\">Typically, when tweets violate Twitter\u2019s policies, one of the actions the company can take is to limit the reach of those tweets \u2014 or something it calls \u201cvisibility filtering.\u201d In these scenarios, the tweets remain online but become less discoverable, as they\u2019re "https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/rules-and-policies\/enforcement-options\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u00a0excluded from areas<\/a>\u00a0like search results, trends, recommended notifications, For You and Following timelines, and more.<\/p>\n Historically, the wider public would not necessarily know if a tweet had been moderated in this way. Now Twitter says that will change.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/13\/twitter-introduces-10000-character-long-tweets-for-blue-subscribers\/\">10,000-character-long tweets for Blue subscribers<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">Twitter’s new feature will let Blue subscribers post 10,000-character-long posts \u2014 as if the social network is "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/07\/twitter-substack-censorship-retweet\/\">trying to compete with a rival newsletter platform<\/a>. Twitter has also added support for bold and italic text formatting.<\/p>\n Long-form writing is also not entirely new. Last June, the company introduced a program called\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/06\/22\/twitter-officially-rolls-out-its-long-form-content-notes-feature\/\">Twitter Notes for select writers<\/a>. However, that program was shut down under Musk. After taking over the company\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/14\/twitter-shuts-down-revue-its-newsletter-platform\/\">he also killed newsletter tool Revue<\/a>, a startup Twitter had acquired in 2021.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/13\/twitter-npr-pbs-leave-elon-musk\/\">NPR, PBS and a handful of other news organizations bail on Twitter as Musk meddles with account labels<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">A PBS spokesperson\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.axios.com\/2023\/04\/12\/pbs-twitter-government-funded-label\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">confirmed<\/a>\u00a0to Axios that PBS had \u201cno plans to resume tweeting\u201d after Twitter gave it a murky \u201cgovernment-funded media\u201d label over the weekend. A few\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/news-organizations-quit-twitter-elon-musk-npr-government-funded-label-2023-4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">other news entities<\/a>\u00a0appeared to have followed suit, including the prominent Boston NPR affiliate\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/WBUR\/status\/1646193751780474901\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">WBUR<\/a>, Hawaii Public Radio and LA-based local news source\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/LAist\/status\/1646233215060021249\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">LAist<\/a>.<\/p>\n The Australian Broadcasting Company (ABC Australia), Australia\u2019s Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), New Zealand\u2019s public broadcaster RNZ, Sweden\u2019s SR Ekot and SVT, and Catalonia\u2019s TV3.cat a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/17\/twitter-adds-more-government-funded-labels-to-global-news-outlets\/\">were labeled “government-funded media”<\/a> weeks later.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/13\/twitter-partners-with-etoro-to-show-real-time-stock-and-crypto-information\/\">Twitter partners with eToro to show real-time stock and crypto information<\/a><\/h3>\n This expands upon the social network\u2019s Cashtag feature, which provided info about\u00a0 "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/22\/twitter-now-displays-stock-and-cryptocurrency-prices-directly-in-search-results\/\">a limited number of stocks and crypto coins through TradingView data<\/a>.<\/p>\n The new partnership with eToro goes beyond just displaying information. It also redirects users to the eToro site where they can engage in trading. If you search for a stock on Twitter, you will see a button saying \u201cView on eToro,\u201d which redirects to the site.<\/p>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">\ud83c\udf89Very excited to be launching a new $Cashtags partnership with "https:\/\/twitter.com\/Twitter?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@Twitter<\/a> which will enable Twitter users to see real-time prices for a much wider range of stocks, crypto & other assets as well as having the option to invest through eToro.
"https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@elonmusk<\/a> "https:\/\/t.co\/Iv2q9iNxbf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https:\/\/t.co\/Iv2q9iNxbf<\/a><\/p>\n \u2014 eToro (@eToro) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/eToro\/status\/1646430266401890304?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">April 13, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/12\/elon-musk-admits-he-only-bought-twitter-because-he-thought-hed-be-forced-to\/\">Elon Musk says he only bought Twitter because he thought he’d be forced to\u00a0<\/a><\/h3>\n "speakable-summary\">Elon Musk gave a rare interview to an actual reporter late on Tuesday, speaking to BBC reporter James Clayton on Twitter Spaces. During the\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/TexasLindsay_\/status\/1646006232484913153\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">interview<\/a>, Clayton pressed Musk on whether his purchase of Twitter was, in the end, something he went through with willingly, or whether it was something he did because the active court case at the time in which Twitter was trying to force him to go through with the sale was going badly.<\/p>\n The answer was that Musk did indeed only do the deal because he believed legally, he was going to be forced to do so anyway.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/11\/elon-musk-says-twitter-will-finally-remove-legacy-checkmarks-on-4-20\/\">Elon Musk says Twitter will officially remove legacy checkmarks on 4\/20<\/a><\/h3>\n This is the \u201cfinal date,\u201d he said in a tweet. That means that your supposedly private posts might breach containment to reach an unintended audience, which could quickly spark some uncomfortable situations.<\/p>\n TechCrunch has spoken to multiple users who have also experienced this glitch firsthand;\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/adamjmoussa\/status\/1644460901779615745\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">many<\/a>\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/AC3ATTORN3Y\/status\/1644526438786146304\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">more<\/a>\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/ERnurse86\/status\/1644733902840365060\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">have<\/a>\u00a0 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/DaricCott\/status\/1644541029641752578\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported<\/a>\u00a0the glitch in their tweets. "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/03\/twitters-new-label-makes-it-hard-to-differentiate-between-legacy-and-paid-verified-accounts\/\">Twitter\u2019s verification changes feel like an accidental On February 8, Twitter Blue "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/08\/twitter-launches-subscription-service-blue-in-india-indonesia-and-brazil\/\">extended services further to India, Indonesia and Brazil<\/a>.<\/p>\n Twitter also announced launching a new Spaces tab with curated stations for live and recorded spaces, along with podcasts. The social network is making podcasts available only to Blue subscribers and \u201csome people on Twitter for iOS and Twitter for Android apps.\u201d<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/01\/twitter-to-end-free-access-to-its-api\/\">Twitter to end free access to its API<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter will discontinue offering free access to the Twitter API starting February 9 and will launch a paid version, Twitter said as it looks for more avenues to monetize the platform.<\/p>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">Starting February 9, we will no longer support free access to the Twitter API, both v2 and v1.1. A paid basic tier will be available instead \ud83e\uddf5<\/p>\n \u2014 Twitter Dev (@TwitterDev) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterDev\/status\/1621026986784337922?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">February 2, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n A week later and days before the February 9 deadline, Elon Musk said that after getting feedback from developers, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/04\/elon-musk-says-twitter-will-provide-a-free-write-only-api-to-bots-providing-good-content\/\">Twitter will provide a write-only API for \u201cbots providing good content that is free.\u201d<\/a><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/01\/twitter-discontinues-cotweets-says-will-debut-text-attachments-next-week\/\">Twitter discontinues CoTweets<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter "https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/using-twitter\/cotweets\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> February 1 that it is discontinuing CoTweeting, a feature that allowed two users to co-author a tweet. Users will be able to view the set of co-tweets for a month. After that, they will be automatically converted to retweets on the co-author\u2019s profile.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/using-twitter\/cotweets\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> "async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter wp-image-2523429 size-full\" title=\"Screen shot by Alyssa Stringer of Twitter's Help Center and policy on CoTweets\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-03-at-6.42.11-PM-1.png\" alt=\"Screenshot of Twitter's new policy in sunsetting CoTweets\" width=\"1014\" height=\"313\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n January 2023<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/25\/twitter-partners-with-doubleverify-and-ias-on-brand-safety-initiative-amid-advertiser-exits\/\">Twitter partners with DoubleVerify and IAS on brand safety initiative<\/a><\/h3>\n Due to declining ad revenue and "https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2022\/11\/01\/technology\/elon-musk-twitter-advertisers.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">advertiser exits<\/a>, Twitter announced on January 25 that it has teamed up with adtech companies DoubleVerify and Integral Ad Science (IAS) to tell advertisers if their ad is placed around inappropriate content. The program, available first for U.S.-based advertising campaigns, allows brands to analyze the content adjacent to \u2014 primarily tweets above and below the ad \u2014 all types of ads, including promoted tweets.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/20\/twitter-puts-more-emphasis-on-the-bookmark-feature-on-ios\/\">Twitter rolls out its bookmark feature on iOS<\/a><\/h3>\n The new design displays the bookmark button under the expanded tweet view, making it easier to add a post to your bookmarks.<\/p>\n Before the change, you had to tap on the share button to open the sharing card and then tap on the bookmark option to save a tweet. In addition to the new button, as soon as you tap on the button, you will see a banner at the top of the screen that says \u201cShow all bookmarks.\u201d<\/p>\n The option is currently visible only on the iOS app, but we can expect that Twitter will roll this out to Android and the web soon.<\/p>\n "attachment_2473025\" style=\"width: 416px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\"> "caption-attachment-2473025\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical wp-image-2473025 size-large\" Image Credits:<\/strong> Twitter<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/19\/twitter-officially-bans-third-party-clients-after-cutting-off-prominent-devs\/\">Twitter quietly bans third-party clients<\/a><\/h3>\n After "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/16\/twitters-third-party-client-issue-is-seemingly-a-deliberate-suspension\/\">cutting off prominent app makers<\/a> like Tweetbot and Twitterific, Twitter quietly updated its developer terms to "https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/twitter-new-developer-terms-ban-third-party-clients-211247096.html?src=rss\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ban third-party clients altogether<\/a> on January 19.<\/p>\n The \u201crestrictions\u201d section of the company’s "https:\/\/developer.twitter.com\/en\/developer-terms\/agreement\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">developer agreement<\/a> was updated with a clause prohibiting \u201cuse or access the Licensed Materials to create or attempt to create a substitute or similar service or product to the Twitter Applications.\u201d Earlier in the week, the company said that it was \u201cenforcing long-standing API rules\u201d in disallowing clients access to its platform but didn\u2019t cite which specific rules developers were violating.<\/p>\n As a result, third-party Twitter clients began "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/19\/twitterrific-tweetbot-app-store-removal-twitter-api\/\">offloading their apps from App Stores<\/a>.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/18\/twitter-now-offers-an-annual-blue-subscription-for-hardcore-users\/\">Twitter now offers an annual Blue subscription<\/a><\/h3>\n Users now have a chance to get a discount for $84\/year if they purchase an annual Blue subscription on the web.<\/p>\n Twitter Blue, including the new annual plan, is currently available in the U.S., the U.K., Canada, class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Twitter<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/17\/twitter-office-furniture-auction\/\">Twitter HQ furniture auctions<\/a><\/h3>\n In a strange attempt to make money, Twitter is "https:\/\/bid.hgpauction.com\/past-auctions\/herita10194\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">auctioning off surplus office furniture<\/a> (auction is now closed) that it doesn\u2019t need anymore, now that thousands of employees have either "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/18\/elon-musk-talked-about-laying-off-75-of-employees-he-may-have-just-gotten-his-wish\/\">left the company<\/a> or been "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/07\/after-laying-off-half-of-its-staff-twitter-might-be-asking-some-employees-to-come-back\/\">laid off<\/a>. When you\u2019re rapidly losing advertisers and apparently "https:\/\/www.engadget.com\/twitter-sued-for-not-paying-san-francisco-office-rent-165530970.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">not paying your rent<\/a>, why not go for the hail mary?<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/11\/twitter-makes-algorithmic-timeline-default-on-ios\/\">Twitter makes algorithmic \u201cFor You\u201d timeline the default<\/a><\/h3>\n The company has tried to pull "https:\/\/blog.twitter.com\/official\/en_us\/a\/2016\/never-miss-important-tweets-from-people-you-follow.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">this stunt previously<\/a>, only to give the option to switch back to a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/09\/17\/twitter-chronological-timeline\/\">chronological timeline after a lot of backlashes<\/a>.<\/p>\n What\u2019s different this time? The Elon Musk-led company is now showing both algorithmic and chronological feeds side-by-side. Users can switch between them by swiping on their phone screens. Until now, users had to tap on the sparkle icon in the top-right corner to switch between the \u201cHome\u201d and \u201cLatest\u201d timelines. Twitter is justifying its latest change by saying that users can now easily swipe between the renamed \u201cFor You\u201d and \u201cFollowing\u201d timelines.<\/p>\n \n "1\">January 13: Twitter rolled out the dual-timeline update to the web but at that time the social network used to remember your choice.<\/li>\n "1\">January 20: The company made the \u201cFor You\u201d feed default on the web when users first opened Twitter in a tab or refreshed the page.<\/li>\n "1\">January 24: Now, Twitter remembers your choices again.<\/li>\n "1\">February 7: Twitter remembers your choices again on "background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/06\/twitter-will-stop-forcing-its-algorithmic-timeline-on-ios-and-android\/\">iOS and Android<\/a> "font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">, too.<\/span><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">You can now easily switch between \u201cFor you\u201d and \u201cFollowing\u201d on web. Android coming soon \ud83d\udc40<\/p>\n \u2014 Twitter Support (@TwitterSupport) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterSupport\/status\/1613968597692317701?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">January 13, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/04\/twitters-advanced-search-filters-for-mobile-are-on-their-way\/\">Twitter\u2019s advanced search filters for mobile are said to be coming soon<\/a><\/h3>\n According to social media analyst Matt Navarra, Twitter\u2019s advanced search filters for mobile are coming soon.<\/p>\n Here\u2019s what it looks like:<\/p>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">NEW! Twitter Advanced Search feature on iOS is coming soon \ud83d\udc40\ud83d\udc47 "https:\/\/t.co\/ae56yE3JTU\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https:\/\/t.co\/ae56yE3JTU<\/a> "https:\/\/t.co\/xbQUpQJAlS\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/xbQUpQJAlS<\/a><\/p>\n \u2014 Matt Navarra (@MattNavarra) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MattNavarra\/status\/1610714307070930944?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">January 4, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/03\/twitter-is-set-to-reverse-the-political-ad-ban-to-bolster-up-its-revenue\/\">Twitter lifts the political ad ban to bolster revenue<\/a><\/h3>\n The company originally "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/11\/15\/twitter-makes-its-political-ad-ban-official\/\">enforced the ban back in 2019<\/a>. At that time, it said that \u201cpolitical message reach should be earned, not bought.\u201d Twitter charted a different path from other social networks like Facebook and Instagram, which allowed political ads.<\/p>\n The company’s announcement to lift the political ad ban comes at a time when "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/musk-blames-activist-groups-for-major-advertisers-pausing-spending-on-twitter\/\">advertisers have been pulling back spending<\/a> on the platform, and the company has been cutting down its "https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2022\/12\/02\/technology\/twitter-advertising-targets-missed.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">internal revenue projections.<\/a><\/p>\n December 2022<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/22\/twitter-blue-users-can-now-upload-60-minute-long-videos\/\">Twitter Blue users can now upload 60-minute videos<\/a><\/h3>\n On December 23, the "https:\/\/help.twitter.com\/en\/using-twitter\/twitter-blue\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter Blue page<\/a> was updated declaring that subscribers can now upload 60-minute videos from the web at 1080p resolution and 2GB in file size.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/22\/twitter-lays-off-employees-in-public-policy-engineering\/\">Layoffs continue, impacting employees in public policy, engineering<\/a><\/h3>\n According to posts on "https:\/\/twitter.com\/theodoraskeadas\/status\/1605953310451720195\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter<\/a> and "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/feed\/update\/urn:li:activity:7011716808877428736\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">LinkedIn<\/a> from a former public policy employee on December 22, Twitter cut half of its public policy team.<\/p>\n The company also laid off some engineers in infrastructure via email on December 16. Across all of Twitter, it\u2019s estimated that about 75% of employees have either chosen to leave or have been laid off since Elon Musk took ownership of the company in October.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/22\/twitter-now-displays-stock-and-cryptocurrency-prices-directly-in-search-results\/\">Twitter now displays stock and cryptocurrency prices directly in search results<\/a><\/h3>\n To access the new feature, users have to just type the dollar symbol followed by the relevant ticker symbol, e.g. \u201c$GOOG\u201d or \u201c$ETH\u201d (minus the quote marks), in the search bar and Twitter will display the current price. This also works without using the $ symbol in some instances, but it\u2019s less consistent and doesn\u2019t always return the stock or crypto prices as requested.<\/p>\n If someone wants to know more details about a stock or cryptocurrency, they can hit the \u201cView on Robinhood\u201d button.<\/p>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">$Cashtags, now with data \ud83d\udcc8<\/p>\n \ud83d\udc40 "https:\/\/twitter.com\/search?q=%24SPY&src=ctag&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$SPY<\/a> \ud83d\udc47 "https:\/\/t.co\/XgOK6gf02E\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/XgOK6gf02E<\/a><\/p>\n \u2014 Twitter Business (@TwitterBusiness) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterBusiness\/status\/1605651865818914816?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">December 21, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/22\/twitter-now-shows-how-many-people-view-your-tweets\/\">You can now see how many people view your tweets<\/a><\/h3>\n A tweet\u2019s View Count will be visible to everyone, not just the owner of the account.<\/p>\n \u201cTwitter is rolling out View Count, so you can see how many times a tweet has been seen! This is normal for video,\u201d "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1605957811162054656\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Elon Musk wrote in a tweet<\/a>. \u201cShows how much more alive Twitter is than it may seem, as over 90% of Twitter users read, but don\u2019t tweet, reply or like, as those are public actions.\u201d<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/19\/twitter-blue-for-business-now-allows-companies-to-identify-their-employees\/\">Twitter Blue for Business now allows companies to identify their employees<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter\u2019s product manager "https:\/\/twitter.com\/esthercrawford\/status\/1604956453932236800?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1604956453932236800%7Ctwgr%5Eebeef9515450b8635d41b88e97957eda0559c971%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Ftechcrunch.com%2F2022%2F12%2F19%2Ftwitter-blue-for-business-now-allows-companies-to-identify-their-employees%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Esther Crawford said<\/a> the social media platform is launching a pilot program for Blue for Business with select businesses. The company plans to expand this to more organizations next year.<\/p>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">We\u2019re launching the pilot of Blue for Business so beginning today you\u2019ll start seeing company badges on select profiles. We\u2019ll soon be expanding the program and look forward to having more businesses added in the new year! "https:\/\/t.co\/ytnMRO5rcE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https:\/\/t.co\/ytnMRO5rcE<\/a><\/p>\n \u2014 Esther Crawford \u2728 (@esthercrawford) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/esthercrawford\/status\/1604956453932236800?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">December 19, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/15\/twitter-just-banned-a-wave-of-prominent-journalists-with-no-explanation\/\">Twitter goes on an account suspension spree, including prominent journalists<\/a><\/h3>\n A day after Twitter crafted a new policy to explain its decision to ban an account that tracks "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/14\/elon-jet-the-twitter-account-tracking-elon-musks-flights-was-permanently-suspended\/\">Elon Musk\u2019s private jet<\/a>, Twitter "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/15\/elon-musk-suspends-mastodon-twitter-account-over-elonjet-tracking\/\">also suspended<\/a> its "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/08\/what-is-mastodon\/\">open source competitor Mastodon<\/a> from the service.<\/p>\n Within the same day, Twitter suspended a number of prominent journalists on the platform without warning. \u201cSame doxxing rules apply to \u2018journalists\u2019 as to everyone else,\u201d "https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1603573725978275841?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1603573725978275841%7Ctwgr%5E37fd6aa460cc6b9594a70a0193d1a10b8ae14ca4%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Ftechcrunch.com%2F2022%2F12%2F15%2Ftwitter-just-banned-a-wave-of-prominent-journalists-with-no-explanation%2F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Elon Musk tweeted in a reply<\/a> about the journalists’ suspensions.<\/p>\n The company seemingly had a glitch that allowed banned users to still participate in Twitter Spaces. A group of the banned journalists started a group conversation on Spaces where Musk himself joined in. Shortly after, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/16\/twitter-pulls-its-spaces-group-audio-feature-after-musk-run-in-with-banned-journalists\/\">the app pulled its Spaces group audio feature<\/a> temporarily.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/14\/twitter-shuts-down-revue-its-newsletter-platform\/\">Twitter shuts down Revue, its newsletter platform<\/a><\/h3>\n Revue, the newsletter platform "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/26\/twitter-acquires-revue\/\">acquired by Twitter<\/a> in January 2021, "https:\/\/twitter.com\/MattNavarra\/status\/1603066475656495109\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sent a message to newsletter writers<\/a> on December 14 declaring, \u201cWe\u2019ve made the difficult decision to shut down Revue.\u201d Writers had until January 18, 2023 to retrieve their data before everything was deleted.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/12\/twitter-disperses-the-trust-safety-council-after-key-members-resigned\/\">Twitter disperses the Trust & Safety Council<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter dispersed the advisory group consisting of roughly 100 independent researchers and human rights activists from around the world. The council members received an email on Monday, December 12 from the company saying that the Trust & Safety Council is \u201cnot the best structure\u201d to get external insights into the company product and policy strategy.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/12\/elon-says-twitter-will-remove-all-legacy-verifications-in-a-few-months\/\">Elon Musk says Twitter will remove all legacy verifications \u2018in a few months\u2019<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter will remove all legacy blue checkmarks \u201cin a few months,\u201d Elon Musk tweeted on December 12. Before Musk bought Twitter, checkmarks were used to verify individuals and entities as active, authentic and notable accounts of interest.<\/p>\n This past week, many blue checkmark holders have been seeing a pop-up when they click on their blue checkmark that reads, \u201cThis is a legacy verified account. It may or may not be notable.\u201d<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/11\/twitter-blue-to-relaunch-with-actual-verification-process-higher-price-for-apple-users\/\">Twitter Blue relaunches with new verification process, plus Blue for Business<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter is officially bringing back the Twitter Blue subscription on December 12, starting in five countries before "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/10\/twitter-launches-its-blue-subscription-service-in-japan\/\">rapidly expanding to others<\/a>. The app "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/12\/twitter-will-require-phone-number-verification-to-purchase-a-twitter-blue-subscription\/\">updated its terms to specify that users will need to verify their phone numbers<\/a> before purchasing the Twitter Blue subscription.<\/p>\n Web sign-ups will cost $8 per month and iOS sign ups will cost $11 per month for \u201caccess to subscriber-only features, including the blue checkmark,\u201d per a tweet from the company account.
"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/18\/twitter-blue-is-now-available-on-android-at-the-same-price-as-ios\/\">Twitter Blue became available on Android<\/a> at the same price as iOS in January 2023.<\/p>\n In addition to the relaunch of Twitter Blue, the company also began rolling out a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/12\/twitter-launches-blue-for-business-grants-gold-checkmarks-to-corporate-entities\/\">new offering called Blue for Business<\/a> that adds a gold checkmark to company accounts.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/12\/twitter-begins-rolling-out-its-community-notes-feature-globally\/\">Twitter’s Community Notes feature is now global<\/a><\/h3>\n Community Notes, previously known as Birdwatch, are now visible around the world. Community Notes is the social media giant\u2019s crowdsourced fact-checking system.<\/p>\n Moderators who are part of the program can add notes to tweets to add context and users can then vote if they determine the context to be helpful. Prior to this global expansion, Community Notes were only visible to users in the U.S.
"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/22\/twitter-is-now-accepting-community-notes-contributions-from-four-more-countries\/\">Twitter added moderators<\/a> from the U.K., Ireland, Australia and New Zealand in January 2023.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/07\/twitter-will-reportedly-charge-11-on-ios-for-blue-subscription-to-offset-app-store-fees\/\">Twitter announces charging $11 on iOS for Blue subscription to offset App Store fees<\/a><\/h3>\n When Twitter launched its new subscription plan with a verification mark on November 9, it charged users $7.99 per month. In an attempt to offset App Store fees, the company is charging iOS users $11 for the new subscription plan \u2014 though the Twitter Blue plan is on halt.<\/p>\n November 2022<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/28\/twitter-says-crowdsourced-fact-checking-system-updated-to-better-address-low-quality-contributions\/\">Twitter\u2019s Community Notes updated to better address \u2018low quality\u2019 contributions<\/a><\/h3>\n The platform\u2019s crowdsourced fact-checking system, Community Notes, are notes written by users that are appended to tweets to provide further clarification and context.<\/p>\n The Community Notes algorithm change involves scoring notes where contributors explain why a tweet shouldn\u2019t be deemed misleading.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/25\/elon-musk-says-twitters-new-multicoloured-verification-will-launch-next-week\/\">Twitter announces a new multicolored verification system<\/a><\/h3>\n Elon Musk announces that Twitter will tentatively roll out a new multicolored verification system where companies will get a gold checkmark, government officials will get a grey checkmark and the blue checkmark will be dedicated to individuals even if they are not celebrities. That means the blue checkmark will be used with legacy verified accounts and folks who buy the company’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/01\/elon-musk-says-twitter-blue-will-cost-8-month-with-regional-pricing\/\">proposed $8 per month paid plan<\/a>.<\/p>\n If you\u2019re confused about all the checkmarks, you\u2019re not alone. Here\u2019s a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/13\/a-quick-guide-to-all-the-checkmarks-and-badges-on-twitter\/\">quick guide<\/a> on what each checkmark and badge means.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/11\/have-you-tried-turning-it-off-and-on-again-elon\/\">Twitter Blue verification chaos ensues<\/a><\/h3>\n On November 9, CEO Elon Musk floated changes to Twitter\u2019s system for verifying user accounts, including charging "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/05\/twitter-begins-rolling-out-7-99-twitter-blue-plan-with-verification-fewer-ads\/\">$8 per month for it<\/a>. The social media company "https:\/\/twitter.com\/SawyerMerritt\/status\/1588960868917968896\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">seemingly<\/a> began rolling out a new tier of Twitter Blue, its premium subscription service. According to a tweet by Esther Crawford, a former product lead, the new Twitter Blue plan wasn\u2019t yet live, but some users saw notifications as part of a live test.<\/p>\n "twitter-tweet\">\n "ltr\" lang=\"en\">The new Blue isn\u2019t live yet \u2014 the sprint to our launch continues but some folks may see us making updates because we are testing and pushing changes in real-time. The Twitter team is legendary. \ud83e\udee1 New Blue\u2026 coming soon! "https:\/\/t.co\/ewTSTjx3t7\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https:\/\/t.co\/ewTSTjx3t7<\/a><\/p>\n \u2014 Esther Crawford \u2728 (@esthercrawford) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/esthercrawford\/status\/1588969361976741888?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">November 5, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/p>\n The company also launched "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/09\/twitter-begins-to-roll-out-grey-checkmarks-for-high-profile-accounts\/\">grey-colored official<\/a> checkmarks for notable accounts such as companies and politicians. But within hours of the launch, Elon Musk killed it. Crawford clarified that the grey \u201cOfficial\u201d labels are still going out as part of the new Twitter Blue product.<\/p>\n The new $8 Twitter Blue plan began rolling out to iOS users in the U.S., Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the U.K with the only feature available at the time being the blue “verified” checkmark. This caused a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/09\/fake-twitter-blue-check-lebron-musk\/\">number of fake accounts<\/a> pretending to be celebrities, brands and otherwise influential people to create accounts and spread misinformation.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/03\/twitter-layoffs-elon-musk\/\">The Twitter exodus begins with mass layoffs and exits<\/a><\/h3>\n Elon Musk laid off 3,700 people on November 3, almost half its staff, shortly after completing the acquisition.
"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/04\/twitter-faces-a-class-action-lawsuit-over-mass-employee-layoffs-with-proper-legal-notice\/\">Twitter was sued<\/a> in a class action lawsuit in response to not giving employees advance notice of a mass layoff, alleging Twitter violated worker protection laws.<\/p>\n A week later, the app reached out to some former employees "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/07\/after-laying-off-half-of-its-staff-twitter-might-be-asking-some-employees-to-come-back\/\">to return<\/a> as they were laid off \u201cby mistake.\u201d<\/p>\n In addition to layoffs, a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/10\/twitter-elon-musk-resignations-yoel-roth-robin-wheeler\/\">round of executive departures<\/a> also swept through the company. In Musk\u2019s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/10\/in-his-first-emails-to-twitter-staff-musk-talks-about-ending-remote-work-and-battling-verified-spam\/\">first email to his new staff<\/a>, he talked about ending remote work and making the fight against spam a priority.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"kRLupZZofr\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/16\/musk-poses-workers-with-a-choice-quit-twitter-or-prepare-to-get-hardcore\/\">Musk poses workers with a choice: quit Twitter, or prepare to get ‘hardcore’<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Musk poses workers with a choice: quit Twitter, or prepare to get ‘hardcore’” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/16\/musk-poses-workers-with-a-choice-quit-twitter-or-prepare-to-get-hardcore\/embed\/#?secret=EvDZZGScyp#?secret=kRLupZZofr\" data-secret=\"kRLupZZofr\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n October 2022<\/h3>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/elon-musk-is-revamping-twitters-verification-system-and-it-might-involve-a-monthly-fee\/\">Elon Musk is revamping Twitter\u2019s verification system<\/a><\/h3>\n Twitter begins overhauling a new and more expensive version of Twitter Blue, the platform\u2019s paid plan, that will reportedly cost $19.99 per month and give users a verified badge. At the time, Twitter Blue cost $4.99 per month in the U.S.<\/p>\n According to a report from "https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2022\/10\/30\/23431931\/twitter-paid-verification-elon-musk-blue-monthly-subscription\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Verge<\/a>, the company plans to remove verification badges from current holders if they don\u2019t pay for Twitter Blue within 90 days of launching the new verification system.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/27\/elon-musk-bought-twitter\/\">Elon Musk officially owns Twitter<\/a><\/h3>\n Elon Musk closed on his $44 billion acquisition of the bird app on October 27, 2022. The deal came after months of "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/26\/elon-musk-twitter-lawsuit\/\">legal drama<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/12\/elon-musk-lawsuit-memes-twitter-acquisition\/\">bad memes<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/26\/elon-musk-twitter-deal-deadline\/\">will-they-or-won\u2019t-they-chaos<\/a>. After sealing the deal, Musk took "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/28\/twitter-will-be-delisted-from-the-new-york-stock-exchange-on-november-8\/\">Twitter private<\/a> and began "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/27\/elon-musk-fired-top-twitter-execs-including-ceo-reports-say\/\">clearing house<\/a>. On day one, he fired former CEO Parag Agrawal, CFO Ned Segal, general counsel Sean Edgett and head of Legal, Trust and Safety Vijaya Gadde.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Welcome to Elon Musk\u2019s Twitter (now X), where the rules are made up and the check marks don\u2019t matter. The Tesla and SpaceX CEO announced his bid to buy Twitter in April 2022, zealously driven to rid the platform of spam bots and protect free speech; now, it\u2019s the one-year anniversary since he made his name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/599182"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=599182"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2619828,"date":"2023-10-25T14:46:50","date_gmt":"2023-10-25T21:46:50","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2619828"},"modified":"2023-10-26T10:23:03","modified_gmt":"2023-10-26T17:23:03","slug":"roblox-palestine-protest","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/roblox-palestine-protest\/","title":{"rendered":"Kids on Roblox are hosting protests for Palestine"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "featured__span-first-words\">In the Lego-like<\/span> world of "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/roblox\/\">Roblox<\/a>, about a hundred blocky avatars march through a lamplit street, wielding "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/14\/palestine-tech-industry-hamas-israel-war\/\">Palestine<\/a> flags that are larger than their own animated bodies. Characters dressed like cartoonish dinosaurs, steampunk zombies and pastel pink pop stars chant together via instant messages in both Malay and English as they arrive at a stage, where leaders of the Roblox server stand together to dictate when the next march around the pixelated streets will begin.<\/p>\n It’s an unexpected demonstration to find within a children’s game, but the larger a platform grows, the more it imitates the outside world. During pandemic lockdowns, "https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2020\/7\/21\/21333431\/roblox-over-half-of-us-kids-playing-virtual-parties-fortnite\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">more than half of all U.S. teens<\/a> were playing Roblox, a sandbox MMO game that lets users build their own servers and social experiences; even as kids have gone back to school, the game remains incredibly popular with over "https:\/\/ir.roblox.com\/news\/news-details\/2023\/Roblox-Reports-Second-Quarter-2023-Financial-Results\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">65 million daily active users<\/a>. But in times of crisis, the game can serve as an outlet for young people to safely engage in political activity and learn about world events.<\/p>\n When 23-year-old Salsabeel (a pseudonym) found out that her younger cousin was attending these protests, she was so moved that she posted on X (formerly Twitter) about it.<\/p>\n “y\u2019all my cousin is 15 and couldn\u2019t join a protest so she just went to one on roblox bro i\u2019m crying,” she said. The "https:\/\/twitter.com\/funnecfox\/status\/1716574694839611743\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">post<\/a> went viral, garnering more than 6 million views. Between her post and some other viral "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@devotedly.yours\/video\/7293621518729284907?lang=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">TikToks<\/a>, more people caught wind of the demonstrations. Now, the "https:\/\/www.roblox.com\/games\/15059675780\/PALESTINE-Dataran-Tanjung-Mas\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Malaysia-based Roblox server<\/a> has been visited over 157,000 times.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--tiktok\">\n "tiktok-embed\" cite=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@devotedly.yours\/video\/7293621518729284907\" data-video-id=\"7293621518729284907\" data-embed-from=\"oembed\" style=\"max-width: 605px;min-width: 325px;\" >\n "_blank\" title=\"@devotedly.yours\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@devotedly.yours?refer=embed\">@devotedly.yours<\/a> <\/p>\n Kids in Malaysia are protesting on Roblox for a free Palestine \ud83e\udd79\ud83e\udd27 "palestine\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/tag\/palestine?refer=embed\">#palestine<\/a> <\/p>\n "_blank\" title=\"\u266c original sound - kurd\ud83c\udded\ud83c\uddfa\u0641\u0644\u0633\u0637\u064a\u0646\ud83c\uddef\ud83c\uddf4\u2705\ud83c\uddef\ud83c\uddf4\ud83c\uddef\ud83c\uddf4\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/music\/original-sound-6963404519753534210?refer=embed\">\u266c original sound – kurd\ud83c\udded\ud83c\uddfa\u0641\u0644\u0633\u0637\u064a\u0646\ud83c\uddef\ud83c\uddf4\u2705\ud83c\uddef\ud83c\uddf4\ud83c\uddef\ud83c\uddf4<\/a> <\/section>\n<\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/embed.js\"><\/script><\/div>\n “I remember that people were holding solidarity events on Minecraft, or on Club Penguin before it shut down, and I heard about people holding demonstrations on Animal Crossing,” Salsabeel told TechCrunch. “So, using these platforms\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0.\u00a0it doesn’t surprise you, but it’s still bringing this unexpected feeling of joy when people use whatever avenue they have to show solidarity for any movement — for Black Lives Matter, for Palestine, for justice for anyone who needs justice.”<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n While conversation in the server hosting these protests did not seem hostile, it’s possible that we did not see more troublesome comments due to Roblox’s existing moderation tools. Oftentimes, messages will be censored with hash marks for containing certain words and phrases, even if some of the messages in question are not malicious. For example, words and phrases like “Jews,” “Hamas” and “Free Palestine” are always censored within the server, no matter what context they appear in. Still, it’s easy for trolls to get around these blocks by using alternate characters.<\/p>\n The choice of censored words is odd and appears arbitrary, showing a limit on the dialogue that can happen on a platform built for children. The word “Jews” isn’t censored across Roblox, but within the Palestinian solidarity server, it is. Perhaps the server censors terms like “Jews,” but not “Jewish people,” since the term “Jews” can sometimes be used in a derogatory, antisemitic manner. But among Jewish people themselves, “Jews” is very normal speech.<\/p>\n Because of this nuance, Roblox told TechCrunch that it monitors the use of the word “Jews” across the platform to protect it from being used in a pejorative way, which would violate community guidelines.<\/p>\n Meanwhile, the phrase “Free Palestine” is censored, yet other similar shows of solidarity with Palestine are not, such as the phrase “Palestine will be free.”<\/p>\n “We value friendly debate about issues and topics that matter to Robloxians,” the platform’s community standards read. “However, to maintain a civil and respectful environment, we prohibit the discussion or depiction of certain political content.”<\/p>\n Roblox prohibits discussion of candidates who are currently running for political office, or who have run for office in the past. Users are also barred from discussing current elected officials, political parties and, notably, “inflammatory content related to real world border, territorial, or jurisdictional relationships.” So, technically, users are permitted to have conversations about the Israel-Hamas War, so long as discussions don’t become “inflammatory” by Roblox’s standards.<\/p>\n “Blocking phrases like ‘Free Palestine’ is consistent with our Community Standards where we do not allow political content, particularly with regards to ‘content related to real world border, territorial, or jurisdictional relationships,'” a Roblox spokesperson told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n While in the server, we did observe some antisemitic messages filter through, particularly after people joined the server to counterprotest in support of Israel. However, the community tended to self-moderate in these instances by telling these offenders that antisemitic speech isn’t welcome. In a way, it’s impressive to see a community regulate conflict among itself, especially in a place frequented by children and teens who may not be experienced mediators. But it seems that Roblox is monitoring the situation to ensure that the server does not become actively hostile; at any moment, the tides could change.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620127\" style=\"width: 1816px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620127\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout wp-image-2620127 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-25-at-10.45.32\u202fAM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1806\" height=\"1002\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-25-at-10.45.32\u202fAM.png 1806w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-25-at-10.45.32\u202fAM.png?resize=1200,666 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-25-at-10.45.32\u202fAM.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1806px) 100vw, 1806px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620127\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Roblox, screenshot like TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n \u201cWhile our "https:\/\/urldefense.com\/v3\/__https:\/en.help.roblox.com\/hc\/en-us\/articles\/203313410-Roblox-Community-Standards__;!!KZXpRQ!XcCEyqArkseMagw6nKJ76YNXFkHYdbohcNWq9s_4hm6buMXtIjFJ7lUL8X5m1TRsBICUNXa1w7zqkfb2xMSc$\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/urldefense.com\/v3\/__https:\/en.help.roblox.com\/hc\/en-us\/articles\/203313410-Roblox-Community-Standards__;!!KZXpRQ!XcCEyqArkseMagw6nKJ76YNXFkHYdbohcNWq9s_4hm6buMXtIjFJ7lUL8X5m1TRsBICUNXa1w7zqkfb2xMSc$&source=gmail&ust=1698347274791000&usg=AOvVaw11vkvi_qxOOgbXvyTm5lNP\">Community Standards<\/a> allow for expressions of solidarity, we do not allow for content that endorses or condones violence, promotes terrorism or hatred against individuals or groups, or calls for supporting a specific political party,” a Roblox spokesperson said in an emailed statement to TechCrunch. “We have an expert team of thousands of moderators along with automated detection tools in place to monitor our platform and will take swift action against any content or individuals found to be in violation of our standards.”<\/p>\n On Wednesday, the server hosting the protests was taken offline for review for a few hours; however, it eventually returned online. Roblox did not give further comment on the matter.<\/p>\n Roblox has had problems with violent activity in the past. Last year, Roblox had to "https:\/\/www.bbc.com\/news\/technology-63078950\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">remove a game<\/a> that let players fight each other while role-playing as Russian or Ukrainian soldiers. From a content moderation perspective, these virtual political protests may raise alarm bells; even in real life, demonstrations of solidarity have the potential to be marred by calls for violence. Still, Salsabeel sees the value in her younger cousin being able to experience something like a Roblox protest.<\/p>\n “I’m glad that people are showing support in as many ways as they can, even if they can’t physically go there,” she told TechCrunch. “Kids are capable of having productive conversations.”<\/p>\n Updated, 10\/26\/23, 1:25 PM ET with additional clarification from Roblox.<\/em><\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"x7ipz1AYmX\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/19\/meta-instagram-palestine-israel-shadowban-censorship-moderation-bias\/\">Meta has a moderation bias problem, not just a \u2018bug,\u2019 that\u2019s suppressing Palestinian voices<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Meta has a moderation bias problem, not just a \u2018bug,\u2019 that\u2019s suppressing Palestinian voices” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/19\/meta-instagram-palestine-israel-shadowban-censorship-moderation-bias\/embed\/#?secret=rrb4kyT1HJ#?secret=x7ipz1AYmX\" data-secret=\"x7ipz1AYmX\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" In the Lego-like world of Roblox, about a hundred blocky avatars march through a lamplit street, wielding Palestine flags that are larger than their own animated bodies.
