name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/2097093"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=2097093"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=2097093"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=2097093"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=2097093"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=2097093"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2617411,"date":"2023-10-19T14:09:45","date_gmt":"2023-10-19T21:09:45","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2617411"},"modified":"2023-10-19T15:59:24","modified_gmt":"2023-10-19T22:59:24","slug":"all-i-want-from-the-internet-is-homer-simpson-singing-smells-like-teen-spirit","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/19\/all-i-want-from-the-internet-is-homer-simpson-singing-smells-like-teen-spirit\/","title":{"rendered":"All I want from the internet is Homer Simpson singing ‘Smells Like Teen Spirit’"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">In a recent New Yorker essay, Kyle Chayka poses a "https:\/\/www.newyorker.com\/culture\/infinite-scroll\/why-the-internet-isnt-fun-anymore\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">dread-inducing question<\/a>: When was the last time you had fun on the internet?<\/p>\n For his example of pure online fun, he points to a retro Flash gaming site, but I have a more recent answer: The last time I had fun on the internet was about an hour ago, when I found "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@mememusic117\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">this TikTok account<\/a> that uses AI to make Homer Simpson sing \u201990s and \u201900s rock songs like “ "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@mememusic117\/video\/7267181287461489953\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Smells Like Teen Spirit<\/a>.”<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--tiktok\">\n "tiktok-embed\" cite=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@mememusic117\/video\/7267181287461489953\" data-video-id=\"7267181287461489953\" data-embed-from=\"oembed\" style=\"max-width: 605px;min-width: 325px;\" >\n "_blank\" title=\"@mememusic117\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@mememusic117?refer=embed\">@mememusic117<\/a> <\/p>\n Homer – Smells Like Teen Spirit by nirvana cover "cover\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/tag\/cover?refer=embed\">#cover<\/a> "homer\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/tag\/homer?refer=embed\">#homer<\/a> "simpsons\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/tag\/simpsons?refer=embed\">#simpsons<\/a> "3danimation\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/tag\/3danimation?refer=embed\">#3danimation<\/a> "voicifymememusic\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/tag\/voicifymememusic?refer=embed\">#voicifymememusic<\/a> <\/p>\n "_blank\" title=\"\u266c original sound - MEME MUSIC\" href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/music\/original-sound-7267181265449782049?refer=embed\">\u266c original sound – MEME MUSIC<\/a> <\/section>\n<\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/embed.js\"><\/script><\/div>\n This visionary — who uses the moniker "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@mememusic117\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@mememusic117<\/a> — is using a program called "https:\/\/www.voicify.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Voicify AI<\/a> to generate audio deepfakes, along with Blender to make the animated scenes.<\/p>\n I can’t understate the joy that this TikTok account has brought me. I woke up at 2 a.m. last night with a terrifying and unexplained allergic reaction, so I went ahead and canceled my afternoon calls due to the lingering consequences of having a human body on this mortal coil. But then the algorithm bestowed a gift upon me: I saw a low-fi "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@mememusic117\/video\/7273404288519474465\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Homer Simpson singing a Queens of the Stone Age song<\/a> inside of a Minecraft castle while Optimus Prime and Shrek dance around in the crowd. It’s like non-drowsy Benadryl has been injected into my veins. In fact, these TikToks look like something my brain would come up with in an antihistamine-induced midday nap, but I know for a fact that this is not a very realistic fever dream (because, as I discovered last night, I regretfully do not have any Benadryl, which is kind of an issue given the circumstances!).<\/p>\n This is the ideal use of AI: It has tangibly improved my day, and it probably hasn’t caused any real harm in the process, assuming that the voice actor for Homer Simpson and "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Brandon_Flowers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Brandon Flowers<\/a> can take a joke.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n But, like many good things on the internet, the longer you think about Homer Simpson’s rock \u2019n’ roll cover band, the more you start to see the cracks form.<\/p>\n In a Discord server, I linked to a video of Homer Simpson singing “ "https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@mememusic117\/video\/7288286568660438304\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">R U Mine?<\/a>” by Arctic Monkeys and declared it my new favorite video on the internet. But when I think about my other all-time favorites, there’s something cut from the same cloth: Goofy singing Evanescence’s “ "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=czLYl4fM8yk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bring Me to Life<\/a>,” which was posted 9 years ago and racked up over 11 million YouTube views. Only in that video, the voice behind emo Goofy is a real person with real voice acting talent.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/czLYl4fM8yk?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n Can the joy of Homer Simpson singing Green Day compare to the joy of some guy on YouTube doing an extremely good Goofy impression while singing Evanescence?<\/p>\n Judging by @mememusic117’s work, Voicify AI has some pretty solid technology. Still, any product that’ll let you pay to "https:\/\/blog.voicify.ai\/how-to-make-ai-cover-songs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">manipulate an AI<\/a> Taylor Swift or an AI Ariana Grande is going to raise red flags. Remember what happened when an "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/26\/grimes-ai-generated-drake-music-legal-issues\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">AI-generated Drake ft. The Weeknd song<\/a> went viral?<\/p>\n The Drake\/Weeknd song blew up to such a degree that Universal Music Group, the publisher representing both of those artists, "https:\/\/hls.harvard.edu\/today\/ai-created-a-song-mimicking-the-work-of-drake-and-the-weeknd-what-does-that-mean-for-copyright-law\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> filed a slew of DMCA takedowns<\/a>\u00a0to try to scrub the synthetic work from the internet. But the song persists, because once something goes viral, it can never truly disappear.<\/p>\n Though some artists like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/07\/ai-music-generator-dance-diffusion\/\">YACHT<\/a> will go out of their way to train an AI on their music to make new songs, artists like Drake and the Weeknd did not consent to having their copyrighted artworks manipulated in such a way. But, as "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/27\/an-ai-for-art-copyright-considerations-for-artificial-intelligence\/\">we’ve<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/09\/generative-ai-and-copyright-law-whats-the-future-for-ip\/\">discussed<\/a> at "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/21\/the-copyright-issues-around-generative-ai-arent-going-away-anytime-soon\/\">length<\/a>, copyright law is not adequately equipped to make definitive judgments on what derivative AI works are fair game, so it’s the Wild West out there.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n "twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n "en\" dir=\"ltr\">This is more entertaining and elicits the same emotional response that Ready Player One was aiming for "https:\/\/t.co\/EOgfvIVBPh\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/EOgfvIVBPh<\/a><\/p>\n — \u00e5\u03c0d\u00aeew \ud83d\udc22\ud83d\udc22 (@Andrew__Boley) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/Andrew__Boley\/status\/1714788340116120039?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">October 18, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n When I see AI deepfakes of dead songwriters like John Lennon or Kurt Cobain singing contemporary songs, it’s not that exciting to me. So why is Homer Simpson covering Nirvana so euphoric? Perhaps it’s because Homer Simpson is not a real person, and we can delight in the silliness of it all without worrying about how "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/26\/generative-ai-disinformation-risks\/\">deepfake technology<\/a> is getting really, really, really good, and we still don’t know how to deal with it. But even so, there is a real person who serves as the voice actor for Homer Simpson, and real people who wrote, drew and conceptualized him.<\/p>\n Neither Voicify AI nor @mememusic117 responded to requests for comment. But I remained fascinated by this anonymous @mememusic117 character, who has been posting on TikTok since 2020, mostly as a faceless meme aggregator. Now the account is nearing 40,000 followers for its Homer Simpson covers, but every video has a text overlay crediting Voicify AI. The user could just be giving credit where it’s due, but I have considered the possibility that this might be a meme account run by the company itself, even if I don’t have concrete evidence.<\/p>\n In the hyper-capitalist hellscape of the internet, where nearly everything we touch is stained with the fingerprints of mega corporations or venture-funded startups, I’m almost going out of the way to ruin my own fun.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Ky8FtzpN1A\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/07\/ai-music-generator-dance-diffusion\/\">AI music generators could be a boon for artists — but also problematic<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“AI music generators could be a boon for artists — but also problematic” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/07\/ai-music-generator-dance-diffusion\/embed\/#?secret=plbU0Td6ws#?secret=Ky8FtzpN1A\" data-secret=\"Ky8FtzpN1A\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"jVVF6F11p1\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/17\/uh-oh-an-ai-generated-song-by-drake-and-the-weeknd-went-viral\/\">A new Drake x The Weeknd track just blew up \u2014 but it\u2019s an AI fake<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577200439"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577200439"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577200439"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577200439"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577200439"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577200439"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2617221,"date":"2023-10-19T08:06:12","date_gmt":"2023-10-19T15:06:12","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2617221"},"modified":"2023-10-19T08:50:50","modified_gmt":"2023-10-19T15:50:50","slug":"discord-is-growing-its-developer-monetization-efforts","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/19\/discord-is-growing-its-developer-monetization-efforts\/","title":{"rendered":"Discord is growing its developer monetization efforts"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">In a time when "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/25\/twitter-introduces-a-new-5000-per-month-api-tier\/\">X<\/a> (formerly Twitter) and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/09\/reddit-male-fashion-advice-mod-take-over-api-protest\/\">Reddit<\/a> have sequestered API access behind steep paywalls, Discord is taking the opposite approach. A few weeks ago, Discord enabled U.S. developers to sell their apps to Discord users in a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/17\/discord-bots-app-directory-activities\/\">centralized hub<\/a>, and "https:\/\/discord.com\/blog\/best-place-to-hang-out-with-friends\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">today<\/a>, that feature expands to include developers in the U.K. and Europe.<\/p>\n Developers who make apps on Discord — which range from mini-games, to generative AI tools, to moderation bots — earn a 70% cut of sales, with the other 30% going toward Discord platform fees.<\/p>\n “We’ve had an open API since the beginning of our platform back in 2015, and we’ve known the benefits of that since day one,” said Mason Sciotti, a senior product manager in Discord’s platform ecosystem organization.<\/p>\n When Sciotti started at Discord, his team was just himself and two engineers. Now, more than 100 people at Discord are building products for external developers.<\/p>\n “Sometimes, it’s still hard to imagine being more than just the three that we started with,” he told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n According to Discord, the platform hosts over 750,000 third-party apps, which are used by more than 45 million people each month. Right now, "https:\/\/support-dev.discord.com\/hc\/en-us\/articles\/17442400631959-Premium-Apps-Policy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">eligible<\/a> developers can monetize by selling app subscriptions, but in the future, the platform plans to offer tipping and one-time purchases.<\/p>\n "attachment_2617224\" style=\"width: 1700px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2617224\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2617224 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1690\" height=\"1052\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png 1690w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png?resize=150,93 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png?resize=300,187 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png?resize=768,478 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png?resize=680,423 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png?resize=1536,956 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png?resize=1200,747 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-19-at-9.56.47-AM.png?resize=50,31 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1690px) 100vw, 1690px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2617224\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Discord<\/p><\/div><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n In order to sell access to an app, developers must meet certain requirements to make sure they’re in good standing on Discord. But to proactively monitor the open API system for bad actors, Discord has a developer compliance team, which accounts for some of the 100+ new team members who have joined Sciotti’s organization since he started in 2017.<\/p>\n “We’ve got a number of automated checks that happen along the way at all the different stages, but the big ones are our verification processes, where an app can only grow so big before Discord takes a look at it and makes sure that everything is on the up and up,” he told TechCrunch. “Especially when it comes to data privacy, we want to make sure that users understand that by using [an app], this is what you’re consenting to.”<\/p>\n On the safety side, Discord also announced that it’s launching Teen Safety Assist, an initiative to keep teens on the platform safe.<\/p>\n The first two features from this initiative are safety alerts and sensitive content filters. If a teen receives a direct message from someone for the first time, Discord may send a safety alert to the teen to double-check if they want to reply to this person. They’ll also be directed toward safety tools that show how to block a user or update their privacy settings if need be. And if Discord thinks that certain media in direct messages may be sensitive, it will automatically blur the content, so that the user has to click the image if they actually want to view it. This feature, which is opt-in for adult users, is similar to a new measure that Apple "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/05\/new-iphone-feature-warns-about-unwanted-nudes\/\">added to iOS 17<\/a>.<\/p>\n Discord is also launching a warning system, which gives users more transparency into the standing of their account.<\/p>\n “We\u2019ve found that if someone knows exactly how they broke the rules, it gives them a chance to reflect and change their behavior, helping keep Discord safer,” the company said in a "https:\/\/discord.com\/blog\/best-place-to-hang-out-with-friends\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">blog post<\/a>.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Kkws0dk5nC\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/17\/discord-bots-app-directory-activities\/\">Discord doubles down on apps to make servers more dynamic<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Discord doubles down on apps to make servers more dynamic” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/17\/discord-bots-app-directory-activities\/embed\/#?secret=dIltL3o5E6#?secret=Kkws0dk5nC\" data-secret=\"Kkws0dk5nC\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" In a time when X (formerly Twitter) and Reddit have sequestered API access behind steep paywalls, Discord is taking the opposite approach. A few weeks ago, Discord enabled U.S. developers to sell their apps to Discord users in a centralized hub, and today, that feature expands to include developers in the U.K. and Europe. Developers […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574468,"featured_media":2617225,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"2f11b299-aa6e-37ae-a606-837a26c3627c","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-19T15:06:19Z","apple_news_api_id":"f0e3f695-3247-4657-91f2-6461eed52194","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-19T15:50:44Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/A8OP2lTJHRleR8mRh7tUhlA","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577055593],"tags":[34966700,5597],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n Discord is growing its developer monetization efforts | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"In a time when X (formerly Twitter) and Reddit have sequestered API access behind steep paywalls, Discord is taking the opposite approach. TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US","isAccessibleForFree":"True","hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","isAccessibleForFree":"True"}},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/5597"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=5597"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=5597"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=5597"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=5597"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=5597"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2616610,"date":"2023-10-18T12:10:17","date_gmt":"2023-10-18T19:10:17","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2616610"},"modified":"2023-10-18T16:23:27","modified_gmt":"2023-10-18T23:23:27","slug":"after-50000-hours-this-ai-can-play-pokemon-red","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/18\/after-50000-hours-this-ai-can-play-pokemon-red\/","title":{"rendered":"After 50,000 hours, this AI can play Pok\u00e9mon Red"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Almost 10 years ago, the online phenomenon \u201c "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Twitch_Plays_Pok%C3%A9mon\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitch Plays Pok\u00e9mon<\/a>\u201d convened over a million people to play Pok\u00e9mon Red at the same time, with each player\u2019s keystrokes registering as commands for the one pixelated avatar. Now, like a Magikarp growing into a Gyarados, the evolution of technology begs a new question: can AI play Pok\u00e9mon?<\/p>\n For the last few years, Seattle-based software engineer "https:\/\/github.com\/PWhiddy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Peter Whidden<\/a> has been training a reinforcement learning algorithm to navigate the classic first game of the Pok\u00e9mon series — in that time, the AI has played more than 50,000 hours of the game. Whidden posted "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=DcYLT37ImBY\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a 33-minute YouTube<\/a> video telling the story of the AI\u2019s development, and after nine days, the video has amassed 2.2 million views.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/DcYLT37ImBY?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n \u201cWhat\u2019s been super fun to see is how many people are engaging with it,\u201d Whidden told TechCrunch. He uploaded the code he used to GitHub, along with instructions on how to operate and train the AI. \u201cThere\u2019s a ton of people that seem really interested in actually doing this process of creating or designing.\u201d One fan was able to apply his code to Pok\u00e9mon Crystal, another retro Game Boy installment.<\/p>\n The AI\u2019s reinforcement model is Pavlovian, giving the AI point-based incentives to level up Pok\u00e9mon, explore new areas, win battles and beat gym leaders. Sometimes, these incentives don\u2019t perfectly align with progression in the game, yet the failures of the AI are weirdly charming, which is probably why Whidden\u2019s video has gone viral.<\/p>\n In one of the AI\u2019s attempts, it simply stops to stare at the water in Pallet Town — the first place you visit in the game — and never moves. It gets stuck in an area with animated water, grass and NPCs who pace back and forth, meaning that every individual frame seems like a novel experience to the AI, even though it\u2019s just sitting motionless without even getting its first Pok\u00e9mon yet. But this AI isn\u2019t in a rush to \u201ccatch ’em all.\u201d It\u2019s just enjoying the beauty of the Kanto region (or maybe it\u2019s taking an ethical stance against forcing these cute little animals to battle each other\u2026 who can say).<\/p>\n \u201cSo, according to our own objective, just hanging out and admiring the scenery is more rewarding than exploring the rest of the world,\u201d Whidden explains in the video. \u201cThis is a paradox that we encounter in real life: curiosity leads us to our most important discoveries, but at the same time, it makes us vulnerable to distractions and gets us into trouble.\u201d<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n The AI somehow continues to pull on our heartstrings: Later, it experiences something akin to a traumatic event at the Pok\u00e9mon Center. The AI\u2019s success is measured in part by the total levels of all Pok\u00e9mon in your party. But when an AI goes to the Pok\u00e9mon Center and button smashes enough to deposit a Pok\u00e9mon into storage, the sum of all levels reduces drastically, sending a strong negative signal to the AI. With both Pidgey and an unidentified creature nicknamed \u201cAAAAAAAAAA\u201d in its party, the sum of all levels was 25, but once Pidgey is deposited into the PC, the sum is only 12.<\/p>\n \u201cIt doesn\u2019t have emotions like a human does, but a single event with an extreme reward value can still leave a lasting impact on its behavior,\u201d Whidden narrates. \u201cIn this case, losing its Pok\u00e9mon only one time is enough to form a negative association with the whole Pok\u00e9mon Center, and the AI will avoid it entirely in all future games.\u201d<\/p>\n "attachment_2616615\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2616615\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2616615\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"393\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png 1632w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?resize=150,87 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?resize=300,173 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?resize=768,443 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?resize=680,393 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?resize=1536,887 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?resize=1200,693 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-18-at-2.58.26-PM.png?resize=50,29 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2616615\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Peter Whidden on YouTube<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Despite the AI\u2019s ability to experience trauma and admire the pretty pixels of Pallet Town, it\u2019s still just a computer. This AI isn\u2019t able to read and interpret dialogue in the game, so in early iterations, the program would get stuck at an early crossroads in the game. When you reach the second town in Pok\u00e9mon Red, you\u2019re given an item to bring back to the Pok\u00e9mon Professor in Pallet Town. But the AI was having a hard time backtracking to deliver the parcel, making it impossible to progress further. So, Whidden skipped ahead to make each game begin after delivering the package, and with Squirtle as the AI\u2019s starter Pok\u00e9mon, since the early game is generally easier with a water Pok\u00e9mon at your service.<\/p>\n \u201cIn the video, the farthest that [the AI] reaches is Mt. Moon, between the first and second gym,\u201d Whidden told TechCrunch. Caves are notoriously frustrating to navigate in early Pok\u00e9mon games, even if you have an actual human brain. But Whidden recently tweaked some of the rewards in his code and tried a different learning algorithm, and finally, the AI managed to exit the cave and arrive in Cerulean City.<\/p>\n Other researchers have used reinforcement learning to study the use of AI in gaming, like with DeepMind\u2019s AlphaGo, which was the first computer program to defeat a professional Go player. But Whidden\u2019s video has garnered so much attention because he\u2019s so adept at explaining unfamiliar concepts through a familiar medium: Pok\u00e9mon.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"U87kDUFn7W\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/28\/make-your-very-own-ai-generated-pokemon-like-creature\/\">Make your very own AI-generated Pok\u00e9mon-like creature<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Make your very own AI-generated Pok\u00e9mon-like creature” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/28\/make-your-very-own-ai-generated-pokemon-like-creature\/embed\/#?secret=DfAft3yKnf#?secret=U87kDUFn7W\" data-secret=\"U87kDUFn7W\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Almost 10 years ago, the online phenomenon \u201cTwitch Plays Pok\u00e9mon\u201d convened over a million people to play Pok\u00e9mon Red at the same time, with each player\u2019s keystrokes registering as commands for the one pixelated avatar. Now, like a Magikarp growing into a Gyarados, the evolution of technology begs a new question: can AI play Pok\u00e9mon? TechCrunch","og_description":"Read the latest news about pokemon red on TechCrunch","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/pokemon-red\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":1200,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","type":"image\/png"}],"twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","schema":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"CollectionPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/pokemon-red\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/pokemon-red\/","name":"pokemon red | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"description":"Read the latest news about pokemon red on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US","isAccessibleForFree":"True","hasPart":{"@type":"WebPageElement","isAccessibleForFree":"True"}},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577200055"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577200055"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577200055"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577200055"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577200055"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577200055"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2615692,"date":"2023-10-17T11:32:23","date_gmt":"2023-10-17T18:32:23","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2615692"},"modified":"2023-10-20T02:51:22","modified_gmt":"2023-10-20T09:51:22","slug":"when-was-the-last-time-marc-andreessen-talked-to-a-poor-person","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/when-was-the-last-time-marc-andreessen-talked-to-a-poor-person\/","title":{"rendered":"When was the last time Marc Andreessen talked to a poor person?"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen posted a manifesto on the a16z website, calling for \u201c "https:\/\/a16z.com\/the-techno-optimist-manifesto\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">techno-optimism<\/a>\u201d in a frenzied, 5,000-word blog post that somehow manages to re-invent Reaganomics, propose the colonization of outer space and unironically answer a question with the phrase \u201cQED.\u201d<\/p>\n Andreessen\u2019s vision of techno-optimism could seem inspiring: He imagines a Libertarian-esque world where technology solves all of our problems, poverty and climate change are eradicated, and an honest meritocracy reigns supreme. Though Andreessen may call us \u201cCommunists and Luddites\u201d for saying so, his dreams are unrealistic, and founded upon a flawed premise that tech exclusively makes the world better.<\/p>\n First, we need to remember the biases that Andreessen brings to the table, mainly that he is absurdly wealthy (worth an estimated $1.35 billion as of September 2022) and that his absurd wealth is largely tied to the investments of his namesake tech venture fund. So, he inherently is going to push for his techno-optimist vision, because the success of tech companies means he gets even more rich. When you have a financial stake in something, you become biased: This is why, as reporters, we can\u2019t buy Netflix stock, then turn around and write an article about why Netflix is going to have a great Q4.<\/p>\n But money can be blinding. Early on in his essay, Andreessen writes, \u201cWe believe that there is no material problem \u2013 whether created by nature or by technology \u2013 that cannot be solved with more technology.\u201d A16z is increasingly investing in defense companies, including Palmer Luckey\u2019s controversial startup Anduril, which manufactures autonomous weapons. Is war the problem these companies are solving? What does \u201csolve\u201d even mean in the context of conflicts like the ongoing war in Israel and Gaza — isn\u2019t the true solution an end to conflict?<\/p>\n Another inconsistency lies in Andreessen\u2019s assertion that \u201ctechnological innovation in a market system is inherently philanthropic, by a 50:1 ratio.\u201d He references economist William Nordhaus\u2019 claim that those who create technology only retain 2% of its economic value, so the other 98% \u201cflows through to society.\u201d<\/p>\n \u201cWho gets more value from a new technology, the single company that makes it, or the millions or billions of people who use it to improve their lives?\u201d asks Andreessen.<\/p>\n We won\u2019t lie and say that tech startups have not made our lives easier. If we\u2019re out too late and the subway isn\u2019t running, we can take an Uber or Lyft. If we want to buy a book and get it delivered to our doors by the end of the day, we can order it on Amazon. But to deny the negative impacts of these companies is to move through the world with blinders up.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Furthermore, it\u2019s implicit — but not stated in Andreessen\u2019s argument — that these platforms have effectively made large swathes of society renters, and the platforms, the landlords. Perhaps he needs a refresher on the ills of the “ "https:\/\/www.tutor2u.net\/economics\/reference\/rentier-capitalism#:~:text=Rentier%20capitalism%20describes%20a%20system,to%20help%20provide%20public%20services.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">rentier economy<\/a>” and how antithetical it is to innovators and entrepreneurship?<\/p>\n When was the last time Marc Andreessen walked through the streets of San Francisco, where wealthy tech workers pretend that they don\u2019t see the homeless encampments outside of their companies\u2019 HQ?<\/p>\n When was the last time Marc Andreessen talked to a poor person — or an "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/10\/15\/instacart-shopper-activists-are-going-on-strike\/\">Instacart shopper<\/a> struggling to make ends meet, for that matter?<\/p>\n Andreessen\u2019s argument is a contemporary rehashing of trickle-down economics, the notorious Reagan-era idea that as rich people get richer, some of that wealth will \u201ctrickle down\u201d to the poor. But this theory has been "https:\/\/eprints.lse.ac.uk\/107919\/1\/Hope_economic_consequences_of_major_tax_cuts_published.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">repeatedly<\/a> "https:\/\/wir2022.wid.world\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">debunked<\/a>. Again: Do Amazon warehouse workers really get their fair share?<\/p>\n At one point, Andreessen makes the case that free markets \u201cprevent monopolies\u201d because the \u201cmarket naturally disciplines.\u201d As any third-party Amazon seller will tell you — or anyone who\u2019s tried to get Eras Tour tickets — this is a point easily disproved. Andreessen may argue that the U.S. market isn\u2019t truly \u201cfree\u201d in the sense that it\u2019s regulated by agencies and the lawmakers who empower those agencies to enforce policy. But the U.S. has had its fair share of stretches of laissez-faire tech oversight, and each has spawned — not stifled — tech giants strongly inclined to crush competition.<\/p>\n Andreessen\u2019s motivations are further crystalized when he makes a list of whom he considers to be his enemies.<\/p>\n In that section, he lists off what he feels has subjugated society to \u201cmass demoralization.\u201d On this list is a mention of the United Nations\u2019 "https:\/\/sdgs.un.org\/goals\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sustainable Development Goals<\/a> (SDGs), the 17 objectives that were created to inspire nations to strive toward peace. According to Andreessen, these are the so-called enemies \u201cagainst technology and life:\u201d environmental sustainability, reduced gender inequalities, the elimination of poverty or hunger, and more good jobs.<\/p>\n How are these 17 goals against technology and life, when technology is already being used to achieve more life — already being used to make clean water, alleviate mass production and generate clean energy? He has a vague, empty way of writing that leaves more questions than answers; it brings forth the idea that he has probably never read the 17 Sustainable Goals, and that instead he is using it as a code word for something else. Then, Andreessen decries ESG stakeholder capitalism, tech ethics, trust and safety, and risk management as enemies to his cause.<\/p>\n What are you really trying to say, Marc? That regulation and accountability are bad? That we should pursue the development of technology at the expense of all else, in hopes that the world will be better if Amazon stock breaks $200 per share?<\/p>\n Andreessen has a coded way of speaking in general, so it\u2019s no wonder that he takes such umbrage with the UN\u2019s goals of supporting those most at risk. He talks about the planet being \u201cdramatically underpopulated\u201d and specifically calls out the way \u201cdeveloped societies\u201d are dwindling in population, a seeming endorsement of one of the core tenets of pronatalism. He wants 50 billion people to be on earth (and then for some of us to colonize outer space), and says the \u201cmarkets\u201d can generate the money needed to fund social welfare programs. (We must repeat the question: Has this man been to San Francisco lately?) He also mentions that Universal Basic Income \u201cwould turn people into zoo animals to be farmed by the state.\u201d (Sam Altman would no doubt disagree.) He wants us to work, to be productive, \u201cto be proud.\u201d<\/p>\n The missing link here is how we can use tech to actually take care of people; how to feed them, clothe them, how to make sure the planet doesn\u2019t reach such high temperatures that we all just melt away. What is missing here is that San Francisco is already the tech hub of the world and is one of the most unequal places in the universe, both socially and economically. What is missing here is that the technological revolution made it easier to hail an Uber or order food delivery, but did nothing about how those drivers and delivery people are being exploited, and how "https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/technology\/2019\/may\/07\/the-uber-drivers-forced-to-sleep-in-parking-lots-to-make-a-decent-living\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">some live<\/a> in their cars to sustain a decent wage.<\/p>\n There are lines and lines to analyze in his manifesto, but it all goes back to the point that what\u2019s missing here is life: the element of living and all its nuances. He takes an either “you are for technology” or “against it” approach to actually utilizing productivity to help make lives better. He talks about the economic frameworks that life is spun around, without mentioning the intricate ways it actually impacts people.<\/p>\n Plenty of tech giants speak of creating a world they have no grasp on. We watch as Meta founder Mark Zuckerberg \u201cmoves fast and breaks things\u201d and then ends up testifying before Congress about election interference. We watch as OpenAI founder Sam Altman draws "https:\/\/nymag.com\/intelligencer\/article\/sam-altman-artificial-intelligence-openai-profile.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">parallels<\/a> between himself and Robert Oppenheimer, not stopping to think so much about whether or not it\u2019s a good thing to push the limits of technological innovation at any cost.<\/p>\n Andreessen is a product — and an engineer — of a tech bubble that doesn\u2019t understand the people whom it purports to serve.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen posted a manifesto on the a16z website, calling for \u201ctechno-optimism\u201d in a frenzied, 5,000-word blog post that somehow manages to re-invent Reaganomics, propose the colonization of outer space and unironically answer a question with the phrase \u201cQED.\u201d Andreessen\u2019s vision of techno-optimism could seem inspiring: He imagines a Libertarian-esque world where technology fety-tycoon-lets-you-simulate-the-most-agonizing-job-in-tech\/","title":{"rendered":"Trust & Safety Tycoon lets you simulate the most agonizing job in tech"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">If you think you could’ve deflected Twitter’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/31\/celebrity-blue-check-twitter-verification\/\">blue check impersonation<\/a> debacle, then boy do we have the game for you! "https:\/\/www.techdirt.com\/2023\/10\/17\/trust-safety-tycoon-try-your-hand-at-managing-a-social-media-trust-safety-team\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Techdirt<\/a> has released the very fun and not at all stressful game "https:\/\/trustandsafety.fun\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Trust & Safety Tycoon<\/a>, in which you get to simulate running a trust & safety team at a Twitter-like social media startup called Yapper.<\/p>\n Created alongside the Atlantic Council’s Task Force for a Trustworthy Future Web, Trust & Safety Tycoon forces the player to confront the challenging trade-offs of keeping an online platform safe — is off-platform harassment grounds for banning a user? Is use of offensive slang okay if it’s being used by members of the group the slang refers to? Can you allow bots on the platform without devolving into a haven for crypto spam? Can you build a policy around political misinformation without showing bias toward one political party or another?<\/p>\n These questions are less complex in a theoretical vacuum — but in this game, you have to maintain solid user growth, ad revenue, moderation speed and team morale. And even if you can accomplish that, your CEO might lose confidence in you and give you the axe when you make a wrong choice regarding the fate of a provocateur named “BatDung” (yes, this happened to me). Then, you’ll field requests from local law enforcement who want you to let a suspected murderer continue livestreaming on Yapper so that the police can figure out where he’s located. And if you can get through that mess, then you’ll have to figure out how to abide by changing international laws without turning over activists’ user data to authoritarian governments.<\/p>\n "attachment_2615658\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2615658\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2615658\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"335\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png 1688w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?resize=150,74 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?resize=300,148 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?resize=768,379 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?resize=680,335 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?resize=1536,757 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?resize=1200,591 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-17-at-12.32.31-PM.png?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2615658\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> "https:\/\/trustandsafety.fun\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Trust & Safety Tycoon "screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a><\/p><\/div><\/p>\n By the time you finish the game, you’re given the option to keep working at Yapper, start your own company, consult for the government or go into an early retirement. If you don’t choose the option of buying a mountain chalet and adopting a puppy, you’re stronger than I am.<\/p>\n The game is difficult: In my first attempt, I was fired before we reached a Series B because my cautious moderation decisions deflated our user growth and ad revenue. Still, it’s entertaining (though perhaps not as entertaining as Rollercoaster Tycoon) and gives you a renewed understanding of how difficult it is to run a social media platform. Though some moderation scenarios are funny — you’re tasked with determining if replying “OK Boomer” to older users is harassment, or if Bronies are a threat to the safety of minors — many scenarios feel urgent, reflecting the real legislation that is passing through Congress as we speak. Can individual states ban TikTok? Can you protect children from seeing porn without requiring all internet users to verify their age and identity? We’ll see how this plays out in the real world.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"nukkcL0Vz3\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/30\/anime-girl-tax-dating-sim-mschf\/\">I played the anime dating sim that does your taxes for you<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“I played the anime dating sim that does your taxes for you” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/30\/anime-girl-tax-dating-sim-mschf\/embed\/#?secret=lEePaN1QwI#?secret=nukkcL0Vz3\" data-secret=\"nukkcL0Vz3\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"XoiaJcW1B2\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/13\/sex-work-x-premium-subscription-twitter-blue-nudity-porn-ban\/\">Blue checks aren’t protecting sex workers from X’s porn crackdown<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Blue checks aren’t protecting sex workers from X’s porn crackdown” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/13\/sex-work-x-premium-subscription-twitter-blue-nudity-porn-ban\/embed\/#?secret=ZouMGGybkn#?secret=XoiaJcW1B2\" data-secret=\"XoiaJcW1B2\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" If you think you could’ve deflected Twitter’s blue check impersonation debacle, then boy do we have the game for you! News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557788"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557788"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=449557788"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557788"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=449557788"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557788"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2613896,"date":"2023-10-12T12:12:26","date_gmt":"2023-10-12T19:12:26","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2613896"},"modified":"2023-10-12T15:44:47","modified_gmt":"2023-10-12T22:44:47","slug":"ftc-sues-bankrupt-crypto-company-voyagers-ceo-over-false-fdic-insurance-claims","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/12\/ftc-sues-bankrupt-crypto-company-voyagers-ceo-over-false-fdic-insurance-claims\/","title":{"rendered":"FTC sues bankrupt crypto company Voyager’s CEO over false FDIC insurance claims"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">After "https:\/\/www.ftc.gov\/news-events\/news\/press-releases\/2023\/10\/ftc-reaches-settlement-crypto-company-voyager-digital-charges-former-executive-falsely-claiming\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">settling<\/a> on Thursday with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/06\/crypto-broker-voyager-digital-files-for-bankruptcy\/\">bankrupt<\/a> crypto company "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/06\/daily-crunch-after-filing-for-bankruptcy-crypto-lender-voyager-digital-says-it-will-maintain-operations\/\">Voyager<\/a> is permanently banned from handling consumers’ assets. But the government agency also announced on Thursday that it’s suing Voyager’s former CEO, Stephen Ehrlich, for falsely claiming that users’ accounts were FDIC insured.<\/p>\n When a bank or financial service is FDIC insured, that means that a customers’ funds will be protected even if the bank fails. While Voyager promised customers this vital protection, these claims weren’t true, as the FDIC doesn’t insure crypto assets at all.<\/p>\n “When the company failed, consumers lost access to significant assets they had saved, including ongoing salary deposits, college tuition funds, and down payments for homes,” the FTC explained in a statement. Voyager’s customers were unable to access their cash accounts for over a month, and more than $1 billion was lost in crypto assets.<\/p>\n Voyager filed for bankruptcy in July 2022, citing volatile crypto prices and the bankruptcy of Three Arrows Capital (3AC), a crypto hedge fund that owed Voyager $650 million.<\/p>\n As part of the settlement, the FTC is fining Voyager $1.65 billion, but the fine is suspended so that the defunct company can use that money to pay back customers instead. In a parallel filing, the CFTC is also charging Ehrlich with fraud and registration failures.<\/p>\n Government agencies have been increasingly litigious when it comes to crypto companies, especially in light of high-profile failures like the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/04\/sbf-criminal-trial-opening-statements\/\">FTX collapse<\/a> — currently, former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried is "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/sbf-trial-the-latest-updates-from-the-ftx-collapses-courtroom-drama\/\">on trial<\/a> for fraud. Just last month, the SEC charged Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/13\/mila-kunis-and-ashton-kutchers-stoner-cats-nfts-get-smoked-by-the-sec\/\"> “Stoner Cats” NFT series<\/a> for promoting unregistered securities.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"olpsoRJKnt\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/08\/11\/mark-cuban-mavericks-face-lawsuit-over-crypto-voyager-ponzi-scheme\/\">Mark Cuban, Mavericks in hot water over Voyager ‘Ponzi scheme’<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Mark Cuban, Mavericks in hot water over Voyager ‘Ponzi scheme’” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/08\/11\/mark-cuban-mavericks-face-lawsuit-over-crypto-voyager-ponzi-scheme\/embed\/#?secret=6kPPXRY5YN#?secret=olpsoRJKnt\" data-secret=\"olpsoRJKnt\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"3gBfr6GMHc\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/sbf-trial-the-latest-updates-from-the-ftx-collapses-courtroom-drama\/\">SBF Trial: The latest updates from the FTX collapse\u2019s courtroom and Caroline Ellison’s testimony<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“SBF Trial: The latest updates from the FTX collapse\u2019s courtroom and Caroline Ellison’s testimony” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/sbf-trial-the-latest-updates-from-the-ftx-collapses-courtroom-drama\/embed\/#?secret=Yndz5QBUpX#?secret=3gBfr6GMHc\" data-secret=\"3gBfr6GMHc\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" After settling on Thursday with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), bankrupt crypto company Voyager is permanently banned from handling consumers’ assets. But the government agency also announced on Thursday that it’s suing Voyager’s former CEO, Stephen Ehrlich, for falsely claiming that users’ accounts were FDIC insured. When a bank or financial service is FDIC insured, name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/182898"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=182898"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=182898"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=182898"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=182898"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=182898"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2613873,"date":"2023-10-12T11:00:46","date_gmt":"2023-10-12T18:00:46","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2613873"},"modified":"2023-10-12T15:12:02","modified_gmt":"2023-10-12T22:12:02","slug":"creators-raising-venture-capital-unsettling-or-genius","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/12\/creators-raising-venture-capital-unsettling-or-genius\/","title":{"rendered":"Creators raising venture capital: Unsettling or genius?"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">When Slow Ventures announced that it would set aside $20 million to invest in individual creators, GP Sam Lessin "https:\/\/www.vice.com\/en\/article\/7kb9mg\/a-former-facebook-vp-thinks-investing-in-humans-is-the-future-of-vc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">responded<\/a> to onlookers\u2019 confusion with a memorable quip: \u201cit\u2019s def not indentured servitude.\u201d<\/p>\n Though Lessin\u2019s remarks weren\u2019t very reassuring, these sorts of venture deals — investments in people, as opposed to companies — have started to seem a little less bizarre. Companies like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/16\/spotter-invest-youtubers-back-catalog\/\">Spotter<\/a> and Jellysmack underwrite YouTubers\u2019 back catalog in exchange for upfront cash, while "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/20\/creative-juice-investment-creators-youtube\/\">Creative Juice<\/a> will fund a creator in exchange for a cut of revenue over a set term. Mythical, the entertainment studio owned by YouTube stars Rhett and Link, launched a $5 million venture capital fund for creators in 2021.<\/p>\n That same year, Slow Ventures made a deal with "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/channel\/UCAQg09FkoobmLquNNoO4ulg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Marina Mogilko<\/a>, a language learning YouTuber and co-founder of the platform LinguaTrip. In exchange for $1.7 million in capital, she will give the venture firm 5% of her earnings for 30 years — plus, they keep that 5% stake in any IP she develops within those three decades. As she explained to "https:\/\/www.vice.com\/en\/article\/7kb9mg\/a-former-facebook-vp-thinks-investing-in-humans-is-the-future-of-vc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">VICE<\/a>, \u201cIf I wrote a book in 2030, and it’s still selling in 100 years or whatever, they’re still getting 5% of that revenue.\u201d<\/p>\n According to Slow Ventures principal Megan Lightcap, the firm has inked six or seven deals with creators thus far, and hopes to close a few more before the end of the year. Two years ago, when the firm wrote a check to Mogilko, this practice seemed intimidating at best, and predatory at worst.<\/p>\n \u201cHonestly, with any seed-stage investment, it\u2019s risky,\u201d Lightcap told TechCrunch. But investing in human beings as opposed to companies creates extra barriers, legal concerns and moral considerations. \u201cA portion of our creators may wake up in five years and be like, \u2018No, I want to go to law school.\u2019\u201d<\/p>\n And if a Slow-backed creator did decide to go to law school, they wouldn\u2019t pay any penalty to the venture firm. These deals don\u2019t require that creators remain on their YouTube grind forever, but Lightcap explains that this flexibility is why the firm structured deals to persist over decades.<\/p>\n \u201cThe way we keep the cost of capital low is to be deeply aligned with the creator over the long term,\u201d Lightcap said. \u201cWe want to be able to say that in year seven or whatever, if they launch a really interesting company and it takes off and that\u2019s where the value is, we need to be able to participate in that upside to keep the cost of capital inexpensive.\u201d<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Both Slow and Mythical are particularly interested in creators with an entrepreneurial bent. Lightcap says she\u2019s looking for the next "https:\/\/www.themeateater.com\/people\/steven-rinella\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Steve Rinella<\/a> — the multi-hyphenate creator behind the MeatEater series — as opposed to the next iconic lifestyle vlogger.<\/p>\n \u201cWe want to back creators that have multiple ideas and want to be a little more risk-on, and to have more at bats, versus, say, just making a couple of hires and generally investing in content,\u201d Lightcap told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n From a venture standpoint, creator businesses might even be more appealing than an early-stage startup, since creator businesses will almost always be profitable by the time they\u2019re big enough to catch a firm\u2019s eye. Creators generally work toward profitability from day one, whereas it\u2019s normal for even a late-stage startup to be losing money.<\/p>\n Slow isn\u2019t public about most of the creators it\u2019s investing in, nor the terms of their deals. But Mythical is publicly backing "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/channel\/UCoLUji8TYrgDy74_iiazvYA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jarvis Johnson<\/a>, "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/channel\/UCnZx--LpG2spgmlxOcC-DRA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Daniel Trasher<\/a> and "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/@TheSorryGirls\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Sorry Girls<\/a>. Mythical also wouldn\u2019t share how much capital these creators got, but their total fund is $5 million and hasn\u2019t been fully spent yet, so we can make a guess. These creators are likely getting about $1 million in capital, whereas last year, YouTube sensation MrBeast was rumored to be shopping for a $150 million check at a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/25\/mrbeast-1-5-billion-valuation-youtuber\/\">$1.5 billion valuation<\/a>.<\/p>\n That doesn\u2019t mean Mythical\u2019s creators are small potatoes, though. Each of these three YouTube channels have more than 2 million subscribers — such popular channels can sometimes make more than "https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/how-much-youtube-pays-for-one-million-subscribers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$50,000<\/a> per month off of ad revenue alone.<\/p>\n Mythical is a wholly independent studio owned by "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/@rhettandlink\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Rhett and Link<\/a>, which has raised no outside capital or debt.<\/p>\n \u201cIt\u2019s independently financed, which gives us a lot of freedom and flexibility in our investment style,\u201d said Neel Yalamarthy, Mythical\u2019s SVP of strategy. \u201cWe don\u2019t have rigid timelines or targets, though we want all of our investees to grow and build companies that one day could become the size of Mythical, or even greater.\u201d<\/p>\n Though the entertainment industry as a whole has suffered from decreased ad revenue, Mythical looks toward these investments as a way to embrace the changing media landscape.<\/p>\n \u201cA great example is the Sorry Girls, and how they\u2019re working to create content that\u2019s akin to HGTV, but for digital audiences, or Daniel Thrasher, who is very much in the Bo Burnham lane, or Jarvis Johnson, who we think is comparable to Jon Stewart and The Daily Show,\u201d Yalamarthy told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n Mythical is thinking more about how they can invest in a creator to build something akin to a TV channel, while Slow is looking toward e-commerce and apps. Lightcap believes creators are more well-positioned than traditional brands to sell a variety of products while remaining authentic.<\/p>\n \u201cThink about Lola, or any of these next-gen tampon companies,\u201d Lightcap told TechCrunch. \u201cIf they were to launch supplements, it\u2019d maybe feel a little weird and disingenuous to customers, whereas if you have a creator broadly in the women\u2019s health space, they can launch a whole bunch of different products.\u201d<\/p>\n Slow and Mythical seem to be doing well thus far, though it\u2019s still early for their creator investments. But the question remains: Is it ethical to treat a human being like a company and make a deal encompassing all of their potential IP? And is it beneficial for venture funds to underwrite people anyway? If a startup founder is caught doing something awful, they can usually leave and the business may eventually recover. But people are different.<\/p>\n Amid "https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/vlog-squad-durte-dom-rape-allegation-david-dobrik-zeglaitis-video-2021-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">allegations<\/a> of a sexual assault that occurred on his filming set, YouTube star David Dobrik stepped down from Dispo, the photo app that he co-founded. Three venture firms that invested in Dispo — Spark Capital, Seven Seven Six and Unshackled Ventures — "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/03\/21\/spark-capital-decides-to-sever-all-ties-with-david-dobriks-dispo-app-weeks-after-leading-investment\/\">severed ties<\/a> with the app, some promising to donate any possible profits from their investment to organizations helping survivors of sexual assault.<\/p>\n Then again, even \u201ccanceled\u201d creators can still maintain an audience. Despite an additional controversy about "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/12\/david-dobrik-documentary-premieres-sxsw-casey-neistat-reveals-youtube-dangers\/\">a near-fatal accident<\/a> on Dobrik\u2019s set, the 27-year-old remains on the map. He runs a pizza shop in Los Angeles, and he\u2019s one of the "https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/why-david-dobrik-is-going-all-in-on-snapchat-and-pizza\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">top creators<\/a> on Snapchat.<\/p>\n At the end of the day, if something were to go horribly wrong, these firms are only out a few million dollars. In the world of venture, that\u2019s a drop in the bucket.<\/p>\n \u201cMaybe we\u2019ll see a person IPO one day,\u201d Lightcap said.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n networking shapes society and our news coverage reflects and directs that. heim\/","title":{"rendered":"VidCon is still kickin’"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">VidCon is a weird event. Over the last 13 years, the event has transitioned from just a fan convention to an industry-forward gathering where you’ll mingle with venture capitalists and Hatsune Miku cosplayers alike. Now, after pulling off its first-ever East Coast event, VidCon will return to Anaheim, California on June 26-29, 2024.<\/p>\n VidCon is the premier event for online creators, founded by two legendary creators themselves, John and Hank Green. The brothers "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/02\/07\/viacom-acquires-vidcon\/\"> sold VidCon to Paramount<\/a> in 2018, but the conference’s events were cancelled in 2020 and 2021 due to the ongoing pandemic. Still, attendance is on the rise. The flagship event in Anaheim drew 55,000 attendees this year, up 10% from the previous year.<\/p>\n When VidCon announced its first attempt at an East Coast gathering in Baltimore, reception was mixed — it’s hard to imagine such a monstrously large event taking place in a satellite location, let alone one that isn’t known for its entertainment industries. As expected, VidCon Baltimore turned out to be significantly smaller than the Anaheim event. While the expo hall in Anaheim feels like a carnival (you can get strapped into a human-sized claw machine to win a Squishmallow), Baltimore’s expo hall was, you know, a basement in Baltimore.<\/p>\n Regardless, VidCon Baltimore drew 8,500 attendees over four days (the same length as Anaheim’s event). And the smaller stage lets the creator conference try new things, which is useful for an event which, like the rest of the creator industry, has been in flux.<\/p>\n For years, VidCon was almost synonymous with YouTube and YouTubers, but for the first time in 2022, VidCon’s "https:\/\/www.hollywoodreporter.com\/business\/digital\/youtube-tiktok-vidcon-2023-sponsor-1235302310\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">title sponsor was TikTok<\/a>. The creator economy’s new vanguard — like the D’Amelio sisters, the Kardashians for Gen Z — made their first descent on the event. But in 2023, YouTube took the title billing again. It’s indicative of larger trends in the creator economy, that while TikTok was the shiniest new thing for a while, creators are now disillusioned with the app’s "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/20\/tiktok-revamped-creator-fund-creativity-program-beta\/#:~:text=Its%20model%20has%20been%20criticized,launch%20of%20the%20new%20program.\">low payouts<\/a>.<\/p>\n For a decentralized industry of worldwide creators, these conferences offer a rare opportunity to get stakeholders in the same room — so, for the first time, VidCon hosted an industry leadership summit, where creator economy experts and creators could hash out their grievances with the state of the business, and share ideas to make the job of a creator more sustainable.<\/p>\n Even in a smaller environment like VidCon Baltimore, there are too many cooks in the kitchen, and it’s hard to accomplish more than a surface-level exchange of ideas when you’re meeting a room full of people for the first time in a convention center. There’s no word yet on whether or not VidCon will return to Baltimore, but hey, there’s always Anaheim.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"no3EWNqKuN\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/03\/anthony-padilla-and-ian-hecox-usher-in-the-new-era-of-smosh\/\">Anthony Padilla and Ian Hecox usher in the new era of Smosh<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Anthony Padilla and Ian Hecox usher in the new era of Smosh” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/03\/anthony-padilla-and-ian-hecox-usher-in-the-new-era-of-smosh\/embed\/#?secret=7AyIwwR4ES#?secret=no3EWNqKuN\" data-secret=\"no3EWNqKuN\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" VidCon is a weird event. Over the last 13 years, the event has transitioned from just a fan convention to an industry-forward gathering where you’ll mingle with venture capitalists and Hatsune Miku cosplayers alike. Now, after pulling off its first-ever East Coast event, VidCon will return to Anaheim, California on June 26-29, 2024. VidCon is […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574468,"featured_media":2612485,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"f9b10a28-6d5c-31f7-8480-aca3a0fccb2b","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-11T16:01:03Z","apple_news_api_id":"a2b9203a-7538-4437-a899-56e3f4b1602d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-11T22:55:50Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAQ==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AorkgOnU4RDeomVbj9LFgLQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577030456],"tags":[576849806,449549899],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n VidCon is still kickin' | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"VidCon is a weird event.
